<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Retail sales</I>. Excluding energy cost recovery revenues and revenues
associated with PPAs certificated by the Alabama PSC, which generally do not
affect net income, retail sales revenues increased by $1.7&nbsp;million, or 0.2%,
for the third quarter 2004 and $48.7&nbsp;million, or 2.8%, year-to-date 2004 when
compared to the corresponding periods in 2003. See Note 3 to the financial
statements of Alabama Power under &#147;Retail Rate Adjustment Procedures&#148; in Item&nbsp;8
of the Form 10-K for additional information. Kilowatt-hour energy sales to
commercial and industrial customers increased 0.3% and 5.8%, respectively, for
the third quarter 2004 and increased 2.3% and 5.8%, respectively, year-to-date
2004 when compared to the corresponding periods of 2003 primarily due to
improved industrial sales mainly in the primary metal, chemical and paper
sectors. Kilowatt-hour energy sales to residential customers decreased 3.5%
for the third quarter 2004 primarily due to Hurricane Ivan which struck Alabama
in September&nbsp;2004; however, retail sales revenues lost as a result of power
outages from Hurricane Ivan did not have a material impact on Alabama Power&#146;s
net income for the third quarter 2004. For additional information, see &#147;Future
Earnings Potential &#151; FERC and Alabama PSC Matters &#151; Storm Damage Cost Recovery&#148;
herein. For the year, residential kilowatt-hour energy sales have increased
2.0% when compared to the same period in 2003 due to customer growth and a
slight increase in average consumption.


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">33
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>ALABAMA POWER COMPANY</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
RESULTS OF OPERATIONS AND FINANCIAL CONDITION



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Other revenues. </I>The increase in other revenues for the third quarter 2004
is primarily attributed to a $2.1&nbsp;million increase in transmission revenues and
a $1.0&nbsp;million increase in revenues from cogeneration steam facilities due to
increased fuel revenue resulting from higher gas prices when compared to the
same period in 2003. The increase for the year-to-date 2004 is mainly due to a
$5.7&nbsp;million increase in transmission revenues, a $3.1&nbsp;million increase in
revenues from cogeneration steam facilities and a $1.3&nbsp;million increase in rent
from pole attachments when compared to the same period in 2003. Since
cogeneration steam fuel revenues are generally offset by fuel expense, these
revenues do not have a significant impact on earnings.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Fuel expense. </I>Fuel expense was higher in the third quarter 2004 when
compared to the corresponding period in 2003 mainly due to a 45.3% increase in
natural gas prices even though generation from natural gas-fired generating
facilities decreased by 32.1%. The year-to-date 2004 increase in fuel expense
when compared to the same period in 2003 is mainly due to a 27.6% increase in
natural gas prices and a 3.1% increase in generation from gas-fired generating
facilities. The increase in generation from gas-fired facilities for
year-to-date 2004 when compared to the corresponding period in 2003 is mainly
due to an increased energy demand coupled with a 43.5% decrease in generation
from Alabama Power&#146;s hydroelectric facilities. Since energy expenses are
generally offset by energy revenues, these expenses do not have a significant
impact on earnings. See &#147;Future Earnings Potential &#151; FERC and Alabama PSC
Matters &#151; Retail Fuel Cost Recovery&#148; herein for additional information.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Purchased power &#151; non-affiliates. </I>Purchased power from non-affiliates
will vary depending on market cost of available energy being lower than
Southern Company system generated energy, demand for energy within the service
territory and availability of Southern Company system generation. In the third
quarter 2004, purchased power from non-affiliates increased when compared to
the same period in 2003 primarily due to a 101.1% increase in energy purchased
even though purchased power prices decreased by 2.9% during the same time
period. The increase in purchased power expense was also due to increased
capacity payments of $11.3&nbsp;million associated with a PPA between Alabama Power
and a third party. See Note 7 to the financial statements in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form
10-K for additional information. Year-to-date 2004 purchased
power-non-affiliates increased $70&nbsp;million when compared to the same period in
2003 mainly due to a 96.7% increase in energy purchased even though purchased
power prices decreased by 9.7% during 2004. The increase in purchased power
expense year-to-date 2004 is also due to a $16.9&nbsp;million increase in capacity
payments associated with a PPA between Alabama Power and a third party.
Increased purchases were used to help meet the increased energy demand for
retail sales since energy was available at prices lower than self-generation.
These transactions did not have a significant impact on earnings since energy
purchases are generally offset by energy revenues through Alabama Power&#146;s
energy cost recovery clause<I>.</I>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Purchased power &#151; affiliates. </I>Purchased power from affiliates will vary
depending on demand and the availability and cost of generating resources at
each system company. Purchased power from affiliates decreased in the third
quarter 2004 over the same period in 2003 due to a 12.2% reduction in energy
purchased and a 4.4% decrease in purchased power prices. The year-to-date 2004
purchased power from affiliates increased when compared to year-to-date 2003,
mainly due to a 40.0% increase in purchased power prices as energy purchased
decreased by 20.3%. A component of the increase in purchased power expense in
2004 is due to a PPA between Alabama Power and Southern Power that began in
June&nbsp;2003, thus resulting in an increase in the year-to-date 2004 capacity
component of $14.7&nbsp;million. Due to the fact that the contract began in June
2003, year-to-date 2004 energy purchased associated with the PPA increased 51.1
% while the purchased power price associated with the contract decreased 5.0%.
See Note 1 to the financial statements of Alabama Power under &#147;Affiliate
Transactions&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K for additional information on this
PPA. These transactions did not have a significant impact on earnings since
energy purchases are generally offset by energy revenues through Alabama
Power&#146;s energy cost recovery clause.


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">34
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>ALABAMA POWER COMPANY</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
RESULTS OF OPERATIONS AND FINANCIAL CONDITION



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Maintenance expense. </I>The decrease in maintenance expense for the third
quarter 2004 when compared to the same period in 2003 is primarily attributed
to a $4.7&nbsp;million decrease in distribution expense and a $3.1&nbsp;million decrease
in transmission expense. These decreases in distribution and transmission
expenses for the third quarter 2004 are mainly related to a reduction in
scheduled overhead line maintenance due to storm restoration efforts following
Hurricane Ivan in September&nbsp;2004. For additional information, see &#147;Future
Earnings Potential &#151; FERC and Alabama PSC Matters &#151; Storm Damage Cost Recovery&#148;
herein. The year-to-date 2004 increase in maintenance expense is primarily
attributable to a $1.9&nbsp;million increase in distribution expense for overhead
line maintenance, a $1.9&nbsp;million increase in steam expense for supervision and
engineering expense and a $1.8&nbsp;million increase in other power generation
expense for caustic water damage repairs at the Washington County combined
cycle facility.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Depreciation and amortization expense. </I>The increases in depreciation and
amortization expense for the third quarter and year-to-date 2004 are attributed
to an increase in utility plant in service when compared to the same periods in
2003. See Note 7 to the financial statements of Alabama Power under
&#147;Construction Program&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K for additional information.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Taxes other than income taxes</I>. The third quarter 2004 increase in taxes
other than income taxes is mainly due to a $2.8&nbsp;million increase in payroll
taxes and a $1.3&nbsp;million increase in property tax expense as a result of higher
assessed property values when compared to the corresponding period in 2003.
The year-to-date 2004 increase in taxes other than income taxes when compared
to the same period in 2003 is primarily due to a $5.5&nbsp;million increase in
payroll taxes, a $4.0&nbsp;million increase in property tax expense and a $2.6
million increase in the state public utility license tax because of increased
retail revenues.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Interest expense, net of amounts capitalized</I>. The decreases in interest
expense, net of amounts capitalized during the third quarter and year-to-date
2004 when compared to the same periods in 2003 are the result of refinancing
higher cost debt. For additional information, see FINANCIAL CONDITION AND
LIQUIDITY &#151; &#147;Financing Activities&#148; herein.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Income taxes</I>. Income tax expense increased for the third quarter and
year-to-date of 2004 compared to the same periods in 2003 due primarily to an
increase in taxable income, resulting in an additional
$3.6&nbsp;million and $9.0
million tax expense, respectively. Income tax expense increased an additional
$9.6&nbsp;million year-to-date 2004 as a result of various income tax actualization
adjustments.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Dividends on preferred stock</I>. Dividends on preferred stock increased for
the third quarter and year-to-date 2004 due to the issuance of 4,000,000 shares
($100&nbsp;million aggregate stated capital) of 5.30% Class&nbsp;A Preferred Stock,
Cumulative, Par Value $1 Per Share (Stated Capital $25 Per Share) in February
2004.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Future Earnings Potential</B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">The results of operations discussed above are not necessarily indicative of
future earnings potential. The level of future earnings depends on numerous
factors including Alabama Power&#146;s ability to maintain a stable regulatory
environment, to achieve energy sales growth while containing costs and to
recover costs related to growing demand and increasingly stricter environmental
standards. Growth in energy sales is subject to a number of factors. These
factors include weather, competition, new energy contracts with neighboring
utilities, energy conservation practiced by customers, the price of
electricity, the price elasticity of demand and the rate of economic growth in
Alabama Power&#146;s service area. For additional information relating to these
issues, see BUSINESS &#151; The SOUTHERN System &#151; &#147;Risk Factors&#148; in Item&nbsp;1 and
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#151; RESULTS OF OPERATIONS &#151; &#147;Future Earnings
Potential&#148; of Alabama Power in Item&nbsp;7 of the Form 10-K.



<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">35
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">



<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>ALABAMA POWER COMPANY</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
RESULTS OF OPERATIONS AND FINANCIAL CONDITION



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><I>Environmental Matters</I>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><u>New Source Review
Actions</u>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Compliance costs related to the Clean Air Act and other environmental
regulations could affect earnings if such costs cannot be recovered. For
additional information about these issues, including information on certain
environmental litigation, see MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#151; RESULTS OF
OPERATIONS &#151; &#147;Future Earnings Potential &#151; Environmental Matters&#148; of Alabama
Power in Item&nbsp;7 and Note 3 to the financial statements of Alabama Power under
&#147;New Source Review Actions&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K. As of March&nbsp;15, 2004,
civil penalties under the Clean Air Act were increased prospectively to a
maximum of $32,500 per day, per violation. To the extent alleged violations
under the New Source Review litigation are deemed to be continuing, this
increased civil penalty amount could apply to such violations found to continue
after that date.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On May&nbsp;3, 2004, the U.S. Supreme Court denied the EPA&#146;s petition to review
the Eleventh Circuit Court of Appeals&#146; decision in the EPA&#146;s similar New Source
Review enforcement action against the TVA. The case against Alabama Power had
been effectively stayed pending this final resolution of the TVA case. On June
16, 2004, the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Alabama lifted
the stay of the New Source Review litigation against Alabama Power, placing the
case back onto the District Court&#146;s active docket. An adverse outcome in this
case could require substantial capital expenditures and could possibly require
payment of substantial penalties that cannot be determined at this time. This
could affect future results of operations, cash flows and possibly financial
condition if such costs are not recovered through regulated rates.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><u>Global Warming
Litigation</u>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">On July&nbsp;21, 2004, attorneys general from eight states, each outside of Southern
Company&#146;s service territory, and the corporation counsel for New York City
filed a complaint in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New
York against Southern Company and four other electric power companies. A
nearly identical complaint was filed by three environmental groups in the same
court. The complaints allege that the companies&#146; emissions of carbon dioxide, a
greenhouse gas, contribute to global warming, which the plaintiffs assert is a
public nuisance. Plaintiffs seek relief under the federal common law or, in the
alternative, under state law, of public nuisance. The environmental groups
also seek relief under common law private nuisance theories. The plaintiffs
seek a judicial order (1)&nbsp;holding each defendant jointly and severally liable
for creating, contributing to, and/or maintaining an ongoing public nuisance,
global warming and (2)&nbsp;permanently enjoining each of the defendants to abate
its contribution to the nuisance by capping its emissions of carbon dioxide and
then reducing those emissions by a specified percentage each year for at least
a decade. Plaintiffs have not, however, requested that damages be awarded in
connection with their claims. Southern Company believes these claims are
without merit and notes that the complaint cites no statutory or regulatory
basis for the claims. Southern Company and the other defendants have filed
motions to dismiss both lawsuits. Southern Company intends to vigorously defend
against these claims. While the outcome of this matter cannot be determined at
this time, an adverse judgment could result in substantial capital
expenditures.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><u>Other Environmental
Matters</u>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">On March&nbsp;12, 2004, the EPA redesignated the Birmingham, Alabama area from
nonattainment to attainment under the one-hour ozone national ambient air
quality standard. On April&nbsp;30, 2004, the EPA published its eight-hour ozone
nonattainment designations and a portion of the rules implementing the new
eight-hour standard. Within Alabama Power&#146;s service area, Birmingham has been
designated as nonattainment under the eight-hour ozone standard. Under the
implementation provisions of the new rule, the EPA announced that the one-hour
ozone standard will be revoked on June&nbsp;15, 2005. The impact of the eight-hour
designations and the



<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">36
</DIV>

<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">new standards will depend on the development and implementation of applicable
state regulations and therefore cannot be determined at this time.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On May&nbsp;5, 2004, the EPA published proposed amendments to its Regional Haze
rules with respect to Best Available Retrofit Technology guidelines and
requirements. The impact of these regulations will depend on the development
and implementation of the final rules and implementation by the states and
therefore cannot be determined at this time.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In June&nbsp;2004, the EPA issued its recommendations for areas to be
designated &#147;nonattainment&#148; for the fine particle national ambient air quality
standard. Areas within the Alabama Power&#146;s service area that were included in
the EPA&#146;s proposed fine particulate matter designations include counties
surrounding Birmingham, Alabama. Alabama Power owns several plants located
within the counties proposed for the nonattainment designation. The EPA plans
to make final nonattainment designations for fine particulate matter by the end
of 2004.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;For additional information concerning recoverable environmental costs, see
&#147;Future Earnings Potential &#151; FERC and Alabama PSC Matters &#151; Environmental Rate
Filing&#148; herein.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><I>FERC and Alabama PSC Matters</I>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><u>Market-Based Rate
Authority</u>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#151; RESULTS OF OPERATIONS &#151; &#147;Future
Earnings Potential &#151; FERC Matters &#151; Market-Based Rate Authority&#148; of Alabama
Power in Item&nbsp;7 of the Form 10-K and Note 3 to the financial statements of
Alabama Power under &#147;FERC Matters&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K. On April&nbsp;14,
2004, the FERC issued an order that abandoned the SMA test and adopted a new
interim analysis for measuring generation market power. This new interim
approach requires utilities to submit a pivotal supplier analysis and a
wholesale market share analysis, the results of which provide a rebuttable
presumption regarding generation market power. The FERC&#146;s order also sets
forth procedures for rebutting these presumptions and addresses mitigation
measures for those entities that are found to have market power. In the
absence of specific mitigation measures, the order includes several cost-based
mitigation measures that would apply by default. The FERC also initiated a new
rulemaking proceeding that, among other things, will adopt a final methodology
for assessing generation market power.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On July&nbsp;8, 2004, the FERC denied Southern Company&#146;s request for rehearing,
along with a number of others, and reaffirmed the interim tests that it adopted
in April. Southern Company submitted the required analyses on August&nbsp;9, 2004.
In that filing, Southern Company passed the pivotal supplier analysis for all
markets and the wholesale market share analysis for all markets except the
Southern Company control area. Southern Company also submitted other analyses
to demonstrate that it lacks generation market power. This filing remains
pending at the FERC. Southern Company, along with other utilities, has also
filed an appeal of the FERC&#146;s April&nbsp;14, 2004 order with the Circuit Court of
Appeals in Washington, D.C. In the event that the FERC&#146;s default mitigation
measures are ultimately applied, Alabama Power may be required to charge
cost-based rates for certain wholesale sales, which may be lower than
negotiated market-based rates. The final outcome of this matter will depend on
the form in which the final methodology for assessing generation market power
and mitigation rules may be ultimately adopted and cannot be determined at this
time.

the Form 10-K for information on

<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">the FERC&#146;s order related to RTOs and the FERC&#146;s notice of proposed rulemaking
regarding open access transmission service and standard electricity market
design.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><u>Environmental Rate
Filing</u>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">On August&nbsp;2, 2004, Alabama Power made a filing with the Alabama PSC to
establish a specific rate mechanism for the recovery of retail costs associated
with environmental laws, regulations or other such mandates. On
October&nbsp;5, 2004, the Alabama PSC voted to approve the rate mechanism as filed.
The rate mechanism will begin operation in January&nbsp;2005 and provide for the
recovery of these costs pursuant to a factor that will be calculated annually.
Environmental costs to be recovered will include (1)&nbsp;applicable operation and
maintenance expenses, (2)&nbsp;depreciation and a return on invested capital
beginning with 2005 investments and (3)&nbsp;a true up of prior period over/under
recovery amounts. It is anticipated that for the first two years of the
increase, retail rates will increase by approximately 1% ($33&nbsp;million) in 2005
and approximately an additional 1% ($30&nbsp;million) in 2006. In conjunction with
the Alabama PSC&#146;s approval, Alabama Power agreed to a moratorium until March
2007 on any retail rate increase under the previously approved Rate
Stabilization and Equalization Plan. Any increase in March&nbsp;2007 would be based
upon the earned return on retail common equity at December&nbsp;31, 2006. See Note 3
to the financial statements of Alabama Power under &#147;Retail Rate Adjustment
Procedures&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of Form 10-K for further information on the Rate
Stabilization and Equalization Plan.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><u>Retail Fuel Cost
Recovery</u>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">In March&nbsp;2002, the Alabama PSC issued a consent order establishing the current
customer fuel rates, which Alabama Power began collecting in April&nbsp;2002. In
recent months, Alabama Power has experienced higher than expected fuel costs
for coal and gas. Those higher fuel costs have increased the under recovered
fuel costs included in the Condensed Balance Sheets herein. Alabama Power will
continue to monitor the under recovered fuel cost balance in light of these
higher fuel costs to determine if an adjustment to billing rates should be
requested from the Alabama PSC. See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS -
RESULTS OF OPERATIONS &#151; &#147;Revenues&#148; of Alabama Power in Item&nbsp;7 of and Note 3 to
the financial statements of Alabama Power under &#147;Retail Rate Adjustment
Procedures&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K for additional information.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><u>Storm Damage Cost
Recovery</u>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">On September&nbsp;15 and 16, 2004, Hurricane Ivan hit the Gulf Coast of Alabama and
Florida and continued north through the state of Alabama, causing substantial
damage in the service territory of Alabama Power. Approximately 826,000 of
Alabama Power&#146;s 1,370,000 customer accounts were without electrical service
immediately after the hurricane. See Note 1 to the financial statements of
Alabama Power under &#147;Natural Disaster Reserve&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K for
information on how Alabama Power maintains a reserve to cover uninsured
expenses resulting from storms. At September&nbsp;30, 2004, total operation and
maintenance expenses associated with repairing the damage to its facilities and
restoring service to its customers are preliminarily estimated to be $52
million. The balance in the natural disaster reserve was not sufficient to
cover these costs. On October&nbsp;19, 2004, Alabama Power received approval from
the Alabama PSC to record its hurricane related operation and maintenance
expenses in the natural disaster reserve, thereby deferring the approximately
$41&nbsp;million negative balance for recovery in future periods in a manner which
will minimize the impact on customers. See MANAGEMENT&#146;S
DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS&nbsp;&#151; ACCOUNTING POLICIES &#151; &#147;Application of Critical Accounting Policies and
Estimates&#148; and Note (M)&nbsp;to the Condensed Financial Statements herein for
further information concerning the Alabama PSC&#146;s approval of deferring the
costs of the storm. In the event another natural disaster occurs while Alabama
Power&#146;s Natural Disaster Reserve balance remains negative, management will seek
approval from the Alabama PSC to defer and recover these costs over

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">38
</DIV>

<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">time. Failure to receive such approval of such an accounting treatment could
affect the results of operations of Alabama Power.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><I>Other Matters</I>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#151; RESULTS OF OPERATIONS &#151; &#147;Future
Earnings Potential &#151; Other Matters&#148; of Alabama Power in Item&nbsp;7 of the Form 10-K
for information on nuclear security measures. Alabama Power has implemented
plans for the measures ordered by the NRC to be in effect on October&nbsp;29, 2004
and is in compliance with the requirements. Alabama Power currently estimates
its expenditures related to these security measures to total $9.7&nbsp;million, of
which $9.3&nbsp;million will be capitalized. These estimates are subject to change
in the event additional NRC guidance is provided.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On October&nbsp;22, 2004, President Bush signed the American Jobs Creation Act
of 2004 (the Jobs Act) into law. The Jobs Act represents the most significant
revision to the Internal Revenue Code since 1986. Congress must still develop
the regulations that will set implement the requirements of the Jobs Act.
Alabama Power is currently assessing the impact of the Jobs Act on its taxable
income. However, Alabama Power currently does not expect the Jobs Act to have
a material impact on its financial statements.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Alabama Power is subject to certain claims and legal actions arising in
the ordinary course of business. In addition, Alabama Power&#146;s business
activities are subject to extensive governmental regulation related to public
health and the environment. Litigation over environmental issues and claims of
various types, including property
damage, personal injury and citizen enforcement of environmental requirements,
has increased generally throughout the United States. In particular, personal
injury claims for damages caused by alleged exposure to hazardous materials
have become more frequent. The ultimate outcome of such litigation against
Alabama Power cannot be predicted at this time; however, management does not
anticipate that the liabilities, if any, arising from such current proceedings
would have a material adverse effect on Alabama Power&#146;s financial statements.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;See the Notes to the Condensed Financial Statements herein for discussion
of various contingencies and other matters which may affect future earnings
potential.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>ACCOUNTING POLICIES</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Application of Critical Accounting Policies and Estimates</B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Alabama Power prepares its financial statements in accordance with accounting
principles generally accepted in the United States. Significant accounting
policies are described in Note 1 to the financial statements of Alabama Power
in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K. In the application of these policies, certain
estimates are made that may have a material impact on Alabama Power&#146;s results
of operations and related disclosures. Different assumptions and measurements
could produce estimates that are significantly different from those recorded in
the financial statements. See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND
ANALYSIS&nbsp;&#151; ACCOUNTING POLICIES &#151; &#147;Application of Critical Accounting Policies and
Estimates&#148; of Alabama Power in Item&nbsp;7 of the Form 10-K for a complete
discussion of Alabama Power&#146;s critical accounting policies and estimates
related to Electric Utility Regulation and Contingent Obligations.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In addition, see &#147;Future Earnings Potential &#151; FERC and Alabama PSC
Matters &#151; Storm Damage Cost Recovery&#148; and Note (M)&nbsp;to the Condensed Financial
Statements herein for information on the Alabama PSC&#146;s approval of the deferral
of approximately $41&nbsp;million of costs in excess of Alabama Power&#146;s existing
natural disaster reserve associated with Hurricane Ivan storm restoration.
Alabama Power currently has Alabama PSC approval to accrue for a Natural
Disaster Reserve. Alabama Power will consider alternatives that minimize the
impact on customers and will develop a plan to recover these costs, subject to
Alabama PSC approval.

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>ALABAMA POWER COMPANY</B><BR>

RESULTS OF OPERATIONS AND FINANCIAL CONDITION



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>New Accounting Standards</B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">On March&nbsp;31, 2004, Alabama Power prospectively adopted FASB Interpretation No.
46R, &#147;Consolidation of Variable Interest Entities,&#148; which requires the primary
beneficiary of a variable interest entity to consolidate the related assets and
liabilities. The adoption of FASB Interpretation No.&nbsp;46R had no impact on
Alabama Power&#146;s net income. However, as a result of the adoption, Alabama
Power deconsolidated certain wholly-owned trusts established to issue preferred
securities since Alabama Power does not meet the definition of primary
beneficiary established by FASB Interpretation No.&nbsp;46R. See Note (D)&nbsp;to the
Condensed Financial Statements herein for additional information related to the
adoption of FASB Interpretation No.&nbsp;46R.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In the third quarter 2004, Alabama Power prospectively adopted FASB Staff
Position (FSP)&nbsp;106-2, &#147;Accounting and Disclosure Requirements related to the
Medicare Prescription Drug, Improvement, and Modernization Act of 2003 (the
Medicare Act).&#148; The Medicare Act provides a 28% prescription drug subsidy for
Medicare eligible retirees. FSP 106-2 requires recognition of the impacts of
the Medicare Act in the accumulated post-retirement benefit obligation (APBO)
and future cost of service for post-retirement medical plans and may be applied
retroactively to the enactment of the Medicare Act in December&nbsp;2003 or
prospectively effective for the third quarter 2004. Alabama Power elected to
apply this treatment prospectively. The effect of the subsidy reduced Alabama
Power&#146;s expenses for the three months ended September&nbsp;30, 2004 by approximately
$1.6&nbsp;million and is expected to have a similar impact on future expenses. The
subsidy&#146;s impact on the post-retirement medical plan APBO was a reduction of
approximately $60&nbsp;million. However, the ultimate impact on future periods is
subject to federal regulations governing the subsidy created in the Medicare
Act being finalized. See Note (G)&nbsp;to the Condensed Financial Statements herein
for additional information.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>FINANCIAL CONDITION AND LIQUIDITY</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Overview</B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Major changes in Alabama Power&#146;s financial condition during the first nine
months of 2004 included the addition of approximately $534&nbsp;million to utility
plant. The funds for these additions and other capital requirements were
derived primarily from operating activities and net proceeds from security
issuances. See Alabama Power&#146;s Condensed Statements of Cash Flows herein for
further details.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Capital Requirements and Contractual Obligations</B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#151; FINANCIAL CONDITION AND LIQUIDITY &#151;  &#147;Capital Requirements and
Contractual Obligations&#148; of Alabama Power in Item&nbsp;7 of the Form 10-K for a
description of Alabama Power&#146;s capital requirements for its construction
program, lease obligations, purchase commitments and trust funding
requirements. The capital required by September&nbsp;30, 2005 for maturities of
long-term debt is not a material amount.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In October&nbsp;2004, Alabama Power approved a new capital budget for 2005 and
2006. The construction program of Alabama Power is $902&nbsp;million for 2005 and
$921&nbsp;million for 2006. Over the next two years, Alabama Power estimates
spending $563&nbsp;million on environmental related additions, $170&nbsp;million on Plant
Farley, $511&nbsp;million on distribution facilities and $249&nbsp;million on
transmission additions. See Note 7 to the financial statements of Alabama
Power under &#147;Construction Program&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K for additional
details.

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>ALABAMA POWER COMPANY</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
RESULTS OF OPERATIONS AND FINANCIAL CONDITION



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Sources of Capital</B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">In addition to the financing activities described below,
Alabama Power plans to obtain the funds required for construction and other
purposes from sources similar to those used in the past. The amount, type and
timing of any financings &#151; if needed &#151; will depend upon maintenance of
adequate earnings, regulatory approval, prevailing market conditions and other
factors. See BUSINESS &#151; &#147;Financing Programs&#148; in Item&nbsp;1 of the Form 10-K for
additional information.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;To meet short-term cash needs and contingencies, at September&nbsp;30, 2004
Alabama Power had $28&nbsp;million of cash and cash equivalents, unused committed
lines of credit of approximately $868&nbsp;million (including $504&nbsp;million of such
lines which are dedicated to funding purchase obligations relating to variable
rate pollution control bonds) and an extendible commercial note program. These
lines of credit will expire at various times during 2004 ($50&nbsp;million), 2005
($593&nbsp;million) and 2007 ($225&nbsp;million). Of the facilities maturing in 2004 and
2005, $225&nbsp;million contain provisions allowing two-year term loans executable
at the expiration date and $245&nbsp;million contain provisions allowing one-year
term loans executable at the expiration date. Alabama Power expects to renew
its credit facilities, as needed, prior to expiration. Alabama Power may also
meet short-term cash needs through a Southern Company subsidiary organized to
issue and sell commercial paper and extendible commercial notes at the request
and for the benefit of Alabama Power and other Southern Company subsidiaries.
Alabama Power has regulatory authority for up to $1&nbsp;billion of short-term
borrowings. At September&nbsp;30, 2004, Alabama Power had $131&nbsp;million of
commercial paper outstanding. Management believes that the need for working
capital can be adequately met by issuing commercial paper or utilizing lines of
credit without maintaining large cash balances.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Credit Rating Risk</B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Alabama Power does not have any credit arrangements that would require material
changes in payment schedules or terminations as a result of a credit rating
downgrade. There are certain contracts that could require collateral &#151; but not
accelerated payment &#151; in the event of a credit rating change to below
investment grade. These contracts are primarily for physical electricity
purchases and sales and fixed price physical gas purchases. At September&nbsp;30,
2004, the maximum potential collateral requirements were approximately $27
million. Generally, collateral may be provided for by a Southern Company
guaranty, letter of credit or cash.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Alabama Power is also party to certain derivative agreements that could
require collateral and/or accelerated payment in the event of a credit rating
change to below investment grade. These agreements are primarily for natural
gas price and interest rate risk management activities. At September&nbsp;30, 2004,
Alabama Power&#146;s maximum potential exposure under these contracts was $9
million.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Market Price Risk</B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Alabama Power&#146;s market risk exposures relative to interest rate changes have
not changed materially compared with the December&nbsp;31, 2003 reporting period.
In addition, Alabama Power is not aware of any facts or circumstances that
would significantly affect such exposures in the near term.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Due to cost-based rate regulations, Alabama Power has limited exposure to
market volatility in interest rates, commodity fuel prices and prices of
electricity. To mitigate residual risks relative to movements in electricity
prices, Alabama Power enters into fixed price contracts for the purchase and
sale of electricity
through the wholesale electricity market and, to a lesser extent, similar
contracts for gas purchases. Alabama Power has also implemented a retail fuel
hedging program at the instruction of the Alabama PSC.

</DIV>

<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;For additional information, see MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS -
FINANCIAL CONDITION AND LIQUIDITY &#151; &#147;Market Price Risk&#148; of Alabama Power in
Item&nbsp;7 of the Form 10-K and Notes 1 and 6 to the financial statements of
Alabama Power under &#147;Financial Instruments&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K and Note
(F)&nbsp;to the Condensed Financial Statements herein.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Financing Activities</B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">In the first quarter 2004, Alabama Power issued 4,000,000 shares ($100&nbsp;million
aggregate stated capital) of 5.30% Class&nbsp;A Preferred Stock, Cumulative, Par
Value $1 Per Share (Stated Capital $25 Per Share) and $200&nbsp;million of Series&nbsp;Z
5.125% Senior Notes due February&nbsp;15, 2019. The proceeds from these sales were
used to repay a portion of Alabama Power&#146;s outstanding short-term indebtedness
and for other general corporate purposes, including Alabama Power&#146;s continuous
construction program.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Also in the first quarter 2004, Alabama Power issued 500,000 shares of
common stock to Southern Company at $40.00 a share ($20&nbsp;million aggregate
purchase price). The proceeds from the sale were used by Alabama Power for
general corporate purposes.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In the second quarter 2004, Alabama Power issued $150&nbsp;million of Series&nbsp;AA
5 5/8% Senior Notes due April&nbsp;15, 2034 and terminated $150&nbsp;million of swaps at
a gain of $6&nbsp;million. The proceeds from the sale were used together with other
funds to redeem, in May&nbsp;2004, $200&nbsp;million in aggregate principal amount of the
Series&nbsp;J 6.75% Senior Notes due June&nbsp;30, 2039. The gain from the terminated
swaps was deferred in Other Comprehensive Income and will be amortized to
income over the life of the Series&nbsp;AA Senior Notes.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In August&nbsp;2004, Alabama Power issued $250&nbsp;million of Series&nbsp;BB Floating
Rate Senior Notes due August&nbsp;25, 2009 and terminated a $250&nbsp;million interest
rate swap at a loss of $0.1&nbsp;million. The loss from the terminated swap was
deferred into Other Comprehensive Income and will be amortized to income over a
five year period.


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">42
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>ALABAMA POWER COMPANY</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
RESULTS OF OPERATIONS AND FINANCIAL CONDITION


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">The proceeds from the sale were used to repay a portion of Alabama Power&#146;s
outstanding short-term indebtedness and for other general corporate purposes,
including Alabama Power&#146;s continuous construction program.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Additionally, in August&nbsp;2004, Alabama Power issued 500,000 shares of
common stock to Southern Company at $40.00 a share ($20&nbsp;million aggregate
purchase price). The proceeds from the sale were used by Alabama Power for
general corporate purposes.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In August&nbsp;2004, $250&nbsp;million in aggregate principal amount of Series&nbsp;K
7.125% Senior Notes matured and also in September&nbsp;2004, $275&nbsp;million in
aggregate principal amount of Series&nbsp;N 4.875% Senior Notes matured. Short-term
borrowing, temporary cash investments and cash provided from operating
activities were utilized to repay the maturing debt.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In addition to any financings that may be necessary to meet Alabama
Power&#146;s capital requirements and contractual obligations, Alabama Power plans
to continue, when economically feasible, a program to retire higher-cost debt
and replace these obligations with lower-cost capital if market conditions
permit.



<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">43
</DIV>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>GEORGIA POWER COMPANY</B><BR>
<DIV align="left">
<A name="122"></A>
</DIV>
<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
RESULTS OF OPERATIONS AND FINANCIAL CONDITION
</DIV>


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">THIRD QUARTER 2004 vs. THIRD QUARTER 2003<BR>
AND<BR>
YEAR-TO-DATE 2004 vs. YEAR-TO-DATE 2003



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>RESULTS OF OPERATIONS</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Earnings</B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Georgia Power&#146;s net income after dividends on preferred stock for the
third quarter and year-to-date 2004 was $287.4&nbsp;million and $586.9&nbsp;million,
respectively, compared to $264.9&nbsp;million and $556.7&nbsp;million, respectively, for
the corresponding periods in 2003. Earnings in the third quarter and
year-to-date 2004 increased by $22.5&nbsp;million, or 8.5%, and $30.2&nbsp;million, or
5.4%, respectively, primarily due to higher retail base revenues partially
offset by higher non-fuel operating expenses.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Significant income statement items appropriate for discussion include the
following:

<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Retail sales. </I>Excluding fuel revenues, which generally do not affect net
income, retail sales revenue increased by $34.8&nbsp;million, or 3.6%, in the third
quarter 2004 and $137.6&nbsp;million, or 5.8%, for year-to-date 2004 compared to the
corresponding periods in 2003. During the third quarter 2004, kilowatt-hour
energy sales to residential, commercial and industrial customers were up by
0.9%, 1.3% and 1.5%, respectively, when compared to the same period in 2003.
Year-to-date 2004 kilowatt-hour energy sales increased by 5.7%, 3.7% and 2.3%,
respectively, in the residential, commercial and industrial sectors when
compared to the corresponding period in 2003. These increases in kilowatt-hour
energy sales in the third quarter and year-to-date 2004 are primarily
attributed to a 1.9% growth in the number of customers, more favorable weather
and continued improvement in the economy when compared to the same periods in
2003.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Sales for resale &#150; affiliates. </I>Revenues from sales for resale to
affiliated companies within the Southern Company system will vary depending on
demand and the availability and cost of generating resources at each company.
During the third quarter and year-to-date 2004, energy sales to affiliates
decreased 25.6% and
6.8%, respectively, when compared to the corresponding periods in 2003. The
increase in year-to-date 2004 revenues for these sales resulted from higher
fuel prices. These transactions did not have a significant impact on earnings
since this energy is generally sold at marginal cost.


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">49
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>GEORGIA POWER COMPANY</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
RESULTS OF OPERATIONS AND FINANCIAL CONDITION



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Fuel expense</I>. The increases in fuel expense during the third quarter and
year-to-date 2004 result from an increase in the average cost of fuel per
megawatt-hour of 13% in each period. Year-to-date 2004 fuel expense was also
affected by a 0.9% increase in fossil generation to meet retail sales demand.
These expenses do not have a significant impact on earnings since fuel expenses
are generally offset by fuel revenues through Georgia Power&#146;s fuel cost
recovery clause. See &#147;Future Earnings Potential &#150; FERC and Georgia PSC Matters
&#150; Retail Fuel Cost Recovery&#148; herein for additional information.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Purchased power &#151; non-affiliates. </I>Increases in purchased power from
non-affiliates in the third quarter and year-to-date 2004 are mainly due to
fluctuations in off-system energy purchases and 27% and 13.5% increases in the
average cost of fuel per megawatt-hour associated with these purchases,
respectively. These expenses do not have a significant impact on earnings
since energy expenses are generally offset by energy revenues through Georgia
Power&#146;s fuel cost recovery clause.

<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Purchased power &#151; affiliates</I>. During the
third quarter and year-to-date 2004, purchased power from affiliates increased
to meet the demand for energy. Third quarter and year-to-date 2004 average cost
of fuel per megawatt-hour associated with these purchases increased 26% in each
period. In addition, year-to-date 2004 purchased power from affiliates
increased $71&nbsp;million when compared to the corresponding period in 2003
primarily due to a PPA between Georgia Power and Southern Power that began in
June&nbsp;2003. The capacity component of these transactions increased $44.5
million year-to-date 2004 over the same period in 2003. The energy component
of power purchased from affiliated companies within the Southern Company system
will vary depending on demand and the availability and cost of generating
resources at each company and will have no significant impact on earnings since
energy expenses are generally offset by energy revenues through Georgia Power&#146;s
fuel cost recovery clause.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Other operations expense. </I>The increases in other operations expense in
the third quarter and year-to-date 2004 are primarily attributed to increases
of $2.0&nbsp;million and $7.1&nbsp;million in transmission and distribution,
respectively, increases of $4&nbsp;million and $2.7&nbsp;million in fossil power
generation, respectively, and increases of $12.8&nbsp;million and $26.2&nbsp;million in
administrative and general expenses related to increased employee benefit
expenses, respectively, and $3.8&nbsp;million in workers compensation expenses for
year-to-date 2004.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Maintenance expense</I>. In the third quarter and year-to-date 2004,
maintenance expense was higher primarily due to the timing of scheduled
generating plant maintenance of $4.8&nbsp;million and $9&nbsp;million, respectively, and
scheduled transmission and distribution maintenance of $7.5&nbsp;million and $16.1
million, respectively, when compared to the corresponding periods in 2003.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Depreciation and amortization. </I>Depreciation and amortization expenses in
the third quarter and year-to-date 2004 were lower compared to the
corresponding periods in 2003. These decreases were caused primarily by lower
regulatory charges needed to levelize purchased power capacity costs under the
terms of the retail rate order effective January&nbsp;1, 2002. These decreases were
offset by increases in affiliated purchased power costs discussed above. See
Note 1 to the financial statements of Georgia Power under &#147;Depreciation and
Amortization&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K for additional information.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Other income and (expense)</I>. During the third quarter and year-to-date
2004, this net expense decreased primarily as a result of increased income from
customer growth, weather and changes in customer consumption related to an
electricity pricing program which contributed income of $10&nbsp;million and $3.6
million, respectively. Also contributing to the decreases in other income and
(expense)&nbsp;is increased AFUDC equity of $6&nbsp;million and $11&nbsp;million for the third
quarter and year-to-date 2004, respectively, associated with Georgia Power&#146;s
acquisition of the McIntosh combined cycle units 10 and 11 construction project
from Southern Power.


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">50
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>GEORGIA POWER COMPANY</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
RESULTS OF OPERATIONS AND FINANCIAL CONDITION


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">See &#147;Future Earnings Potential &#151; FERC and Georgia PSC Matters &#151; Plant
McIntosh Construction Project&#148; herein and Note (J)&nbsp;to the Condensed Financial
Statements herein for additional information. These decreases in the
year-to-date 2004 net expense were partially offset by a reduction in interest
income from the same period in the prior year primarily resulting from $14.5
million of interest on a favorable tax settlement received in the second
quarter of 2003.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Future Earnings Potential</B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">The results of operations discussed above are not necessarily indicative of
future earnings potential. The level of future earnings depends on numerous
factors including Georgia Power&#146;s ability to maintain a stable regulatory
environment, to achieve energy sales growth while containing costs and to
recover costs related to growing demand and increasingly strict environmental
standards. Growth in energy sales is subject to a number of factors, which
include weather, competition, new energy contracts with neighboring utilities,
energy conservation practiced by customers, the price of electricity, the price
elasticity of demand and the rate of economic growth in Georgia Power&#146;s service
area. For additional information relating to these issues, see BUSINESS &#151; The
SOUTHERN System &#151; &#147;Risk Factors&#148; in Item&nbsp;1 and MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND
ANALYSIS &#150; RESULTS OF OPERATIONS &#151; &#147;Future Earnings Potential&#148; of Georgia Power
in Item&nbsp;7 of the Form 10-K.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><I>Environmental Matters</I>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><U>New Source Review Actions
and Plant Wansley Environmental Litigation</U>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Compliance costs related to the Clean Air Act and other environmental
regulations could affect earnings if such costs cannot be recovered. For
additional information, including information on certain environmental
litigation, see MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#150; RESULTS OF OPERATIONS -
&#147;Future Earnings Potential &#151; Environmental Matters&#148; of Georgia Power in Item&nbsp;7
and Note 3 to the financial statements of Georgia Power under &#147;New Source
Review Actions&#148; and &#147;Plant Wansley Environmental Litigation&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the
Form 10-K. As of March&nbsp;15, 2004, civil penalties under the Clean Air Act were
increased prospectively to a maximum of $32,500 per day, per violation. To the
extent alleged violations under either the New Source Review litigation or
Plant Wansley environmental litigation are deemed to be continuing, this
increased civil penalty amount could apply to such violations found to continue
after that date.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On May&nbsp;3, 2004, the U.S. Supreme Court denied the EPA&#146;s petition to review
the Eleventh Circuit Court of Appeals&#146; decision in the EPA&#146;s similar New Source
Review enforcement action against the TVA. The case against Georgia Power had
been effectively stayed pending this final resolution of the TVA case. At this
time, no party to the case against Georgia Power has sought to reopen the case,
which remains administratively closed in the District Court for the Northern
District of Georgia. On June&nbsp;10, 2004, the U.S. District Court for the Northern
District of Georgia granted Georgia Power&#146;s motion in the Plant Wansley
environmental litigation for partial summary judgment regarding emissions
offsets. The case has been removed from the court&#146;s trial calendar due to
pending motions for summary judgment, and a new trial date has not been
scheduled. An adverse outcome in either of these cases could require
substantial capital expenditures and could possibly require payment of
substantial penalties that cannot be determined at this time. This could affect
future results of operations, cash flows and possibly financial condition if
such costs are not recovered through regulated rates.


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">51
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>GEORGIA POWER COMPANY</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
RESULTS OF OPERATIONS AND FINANCIAL CONDITION



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><U>Global Warming Litigation</U>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">On July&nbsp;21, 2004, attorneys general from eight states, each outside of Southern
Company&#146;s service territory, and the corporation counsel for New York City
filed a complaint in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New
York against Southern Company and four other electric power companies. A
nearly identical complaint was filed by three environmental groups in the same
court. The complaints allege that the companies&#146; emissions of carbon dioxide, a
greenhouse gas, contribute to global warming, which the plaintiffs assert is a
public nuisance. Plaintiffs seek relief under the federal common law or, in the
alternative, under state law, of public nuisance. The environmental groups also
seek relief under common law private nuisance theories. The plaintiffs seek a
judicial order (1)&nbsp;holding each defendant jointly and severally liable for
creating, contributing to, and/or maintaining an ongoing public nuisance,
global warming and (2)&nbsp;permanently enjoining each of the defendants to abate
its contribution to the nuisance by capping its emissions of carbon dioxide and
then reducing those emissions by a specified percentage each year for at least
a decade. Plaintiffs have not, however, requested that damages be awarded in
connection with their claims. Southern Company believes these claims are
without merit and notes that the complaint cites no statutory or regulatory
basis for the claims. Southern Company and the other defendants have filed
motions to dismiss both lawsuits. Southern Company intends to vigorously defend
against these claims. While the outcome of this matter cannot be determined at
this time, an adverse judgment could result in substantial capital
expenditures.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><U>Other Environmental Matters</U>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">On April&nbsp;30, 2004, the EPA published its eight-hour ozone nonattainment
designations and a portion of the rules implementing the new eight-hour
standard. Areas within Georgia Power&#146;s service area that have been designated
as nonattainment under the eight-hour ozone standard include Macon (Georgia)
and a 20-county area within metropolitan Atlanta. Under the implementation
provisions of the new rule, the EPA announced that the one-hour ozone standard
will be revoked on June&nbsp;15, 2005. Areas classified as &#147;severe&#148; nonattainment
areas under the one-hour standard will not be required to impose emissions fees
as a result of nonattainment. Georgia Power, therefore, will no longer be
subject to imposition of emissions fees if the Atlanta area does not come into
attainment with the one-hour standard. In any event, however, based on the last
three years of data, the State of Georgia believes that the Atlanta area has
attained the one-hour standard and is in the process of applying for
redesignation from the EPA. The impact of the eight-hour designations and the
new standards will depend on the development and implementation of applicable
state regulations and therefore cannot be determined at this time.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Additionally, on May&nbsp;5, 2004, the EPA published proposed amendments to its
Regional Haze rules with respect to Best Available Retrofit Technology
guidelines and requirements. The impact of these regulations will
depend on the development and implementation of the final rules and
implementation by the states and therefore cannot be determined at this time.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In June&nbsp;2004, the EPA issued its recommendations for areas to be
designated &#147;nonattainment&#148; for the fine particle national ambient air quality
standard. Areas within Georgia Power&#146;s service area that were included in the
EPA&#146;s proposed fine particulate matter designations include 24 counties in the
metro-Atlanta area; counties surrounding Macon, Athens and Columbus, Georgia;
and counties in Georgia near Chattanooga, Tennessee. Georgia Power owns
several plants located within the counties proposed for the nonattainment
designations. The EPA plans to make final nonattainment designations for fine
particulate matter by the end of 2004.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On April&nbsp;21, 2004, the EPA published the final regional nitrogen oxide
reduction rules applicable to Georgia. These rules specified that the State of
Georgia must submit a revised state implementation plan by


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">52
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
RESULTS OF OPERATIONS AND FINANCIAL CONDITION


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">April&nbsp;2005, and affected sources must comply with the reduction requirements by
May&nbsp;1, 2007. However, on October&nbsp;22, 2004, the EPA announced it was granting a
petition for reconsideration filed with the EPA by a coalition of Georgia
industries. The EPA will stay implementation of the rule, as it relates to
Georgia, while it initiates rulemakings to address the petition. The impact of
the nitrogen oxide reduction rules will depend on the outcome of the petition
for reconsideration and/or any subsequent development and approval of Georgia&#146;s
state implementation plan and cannot be determined at this time.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><I>FERC and Georgia PSC Matters</I>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><u>Market-Based Rate Authority</u>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#150; RESULTS OF OPERATIONS &#151; &#147;Future
Earnings Potential &#150; FERC Matters &#150; Market-Based Rate Authority&#148; of Georgia
Power in Item&nbsp;7 and Note 3 to the
financial statements of Georgia Power under &#147;FERC Matters&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the
Form 10-K. On April&nbsp;14, 2004, the FERC issued an order that abandoned the SMA
test and adopted a new interim analysis for measuring generation market power.
This new interim approach requires utilities to submit a pivotal supplier
analysis and a wholesale market share analysis, the results of which provide a
rebuttable presumption regarding generation market power. The FERC&#146;s order
also sets forth procedures for rebutting these presumptions and addresses
mitigation measures for those entities that are found to have market power. In
the absence of specific mitigation measures, the order includes several
cost-based mitigation measures that would apply by default. The FERC also
initiated a new rulemaking proceeding that, among other things, will adopt a
final methodology for assessing generation market power.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On July&nbsp;8, 2004, the FERC denied Southern Company&#146;s request for rehearing,
along with a number of others, and reaffirmed the interim tests that it adopted
in April. Southern Company submitted the required analyses on August&nbsp;9, 2004.
In that filing, Southern Company passed the pivotal supplier analysis for all
markets and the wholesale market share analysis for all markets except the
Southern Company control area. Southern Company also submitted other analyses
to demonstrate that it lacks generation market power. This filing remains
pending at the FERC. Southern Company, along with other utilities, has also
filed an appeal of the FERC&#146;s April&nbsp;14, 2004 order with the Circuit Court of
Appeals in Washington, D.C. In the event that the FERC&#146;s default mitigation
measures are ultimately applied, Georgia Power may be required to charge
cost-based rates for certain wholesale sales, which may be lower than negotiated market-based rates. The
final outcome of this matter will depend on the form in which the final
methodology for assessing generation market power and mitigation rules may be
ultimately adopted and cannot be determined at this time.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><u>Transmission</u>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#150; RESULTS OF OPERATIONS &#151; &#147;Future
Earnings Potential &#151; FERC Matters &#151; Transmission&#148; of Georgia Power in Item&nbsp;7 of
the Form 10-K for information on the FERC&#146;s order related to RTOs and the
FERC&#146;s notice of proposed rulemaking regarding open access transmission service
and standard electricity market design.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><u>Plant McIntosh Construction Project</u>

<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#150; RESULTS OF OPERATION &#151; &#147;Future
Earnings Potential &#151; FERC Matters&#148; of Georgia Power in Item&nbsp;7 and Note 3 to the
financial statements of Georgia Power under &#147;FERC Matters&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the
Form 10-K for information regarding PPAs between Southern Power and

</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>

<P><TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt">

</TABLE>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>GEORGIA POWER COMPANY</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
RESULTS OF OPERATIONS AND FINANCIAL CONDITION


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Savannah Electric and Georgia Power for Plant McIntosh capacity. In April
2003, Southern Power applied for FERC approval of these PPAs. In July&nbsp;2003,
the FERC accepted the PPAs to become effective June&nbsp;1, 2005, subject to refund,
and ordered that hearings be held. To ensure the timely completion of
construction on McIntosh units 10 and 11 and their availability in the summer
of 2005 as supply side resources for the retail customers in the State of
Georgia, on May&nbsp;7, 2004, Savannah Electric and Georgia Power requested the
Georgia PSC to direct them to acquire the McIntosh construction project.
Savannah Electric and Georgia Power proposed to place the units in rate base at
a cost approved by the Georgia PSC and to recover the unit operation and
maintenance costs as retail service expenses as may be approved by the Georgia
PSC. The Georgia PSC issued such an order on May&nbsp;18, 2004 and the transfer
occurred on May&nbsp;24, 2004. On May&nbsp;20, 2004, Southern Power filed a request to
withdraw the PPAs and to terminate the ongoing FERC proceedings. On August&nbsp;4,
2004, the FERC issued a notice that it allowed the request to withdraw the PPAs
to be accepted and to become effective by operation of law on July&nbsp;20, 2004.
However, the FERC made no determination on what additional steps may need to be
taken with respect to testimony provided in the proceedings. The ultimate
outcome of this matter cannot now be determined.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The May&nbsp;18, 2004 Georgia PSC order also directed Georgia Power and
Savannah Electric to file an application within 10&nbsp;days of completing such
purchase to amend the resource certificate granted by the Georgia PSC in 2002
to describe the capacity resource as being the McIntosh units 10 and 11 (as
opposed to the McIntosh PPAs), the approximate construction schedule (which is
not expected to change) and the proposed rate base treatment. The application
was filed on June&nbsp;3, 2004 and the Georgia PSC will have 180&nbsp;days to respond.
The Georgia PSC is expected to review the application in accordance with its
affiliate transaction guidelines, which require a lower of cost or market
approach unless otherwise determined by the Georgia PSC. Georgia Power and
Savannah Electric have submitted information showing that the book cost of the
McIntosh construction project is lower than its market value. In direct
testimony filed on October&nbsp;14, 2004, the Georgia PSC staff proposed a different
valuation that shows the market value for the Plant McIntosh construction
project is less than book value. Georgia Power and Savannah Electric disagree
with the proposed valuation methodology. Georgia Power and Savannah Electric
plan to file rebuttal testimony in November with hearings being held in that
same month. The Georgia PSC is expected to issue a final order in this matter
in December&nbsp;2004. However, full recovery of the project costs depends on the
outcome of the Georgia PSC&#146;s review. In the event the Georgia PSC does not
allow full recovery of the project costs, then part of such costs may have to
be written off in accordance with FASB Statement No.&nbsp;90, &#147;Accounting for
Abandonments and Disallowed Plant Costs.&#148; At September&nbsp;30, 2004, the
investment in the McIntosh construction project totaled approximately $381.1
million for Georgia Power. The ultimate outcome of the Georgia PSC&#146;s review
cannot now be determined. See Note (J)&nbsp;to the Condensed Financial Statements
herein for additional information.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><u>Retail Rate Case</u>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">On July&nbsp;1, 2004, Georgia Power filed a request with the Georgia PSC for an
approximate 7&nbsp;percent increase in retail revenues, effective January&nbsp;1, 2005.
The requested increase is based on a future test year ending July&nbsp;31, 2005 and
a proposed retail return on common equity of 12.5&nbsp;percent. Georgia Power is
currently operating under a three-year retail rate order that expires December
31, 2004. Under the terms of the existing order, earnings are evaluated
annually against a retail return on common equity range of 10&nbsp;percent to 12.95
percent. Two-thirds of any earnings above the 12.95&nbsp;percent return are applied
to rate refunds, with the remaining one-third retained by Georgia Power. The
order required Georgia Power to file a general rate case by July&nbsp;1, 2004.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The increase in retail revenues is being requested to cover the higher
costs of purchased power; operating and maintenance expenses; environmental
compliance; and continued investment in new generation, transmission

</DIV>

on Georgia Power&#146;s filed testimony were held in September&nbsp;2004. Testimony from

<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><u>Retail Fuel Cost
Recovery</u>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">In August&nbsp;2003, the Georgia PSC issued an order allowing Georgia Power to
increase customer fuel rates to collect existing under recovered fuel costs
over the period October&nbsp;1, 2003 through March&nbsp;31, 2005. Georgia Power has
experienced higher than expected fuel costs since the order was issued. Those
higher fuel costs have increased the under recovered fuel costs included in the
Condensed Balance Sheets herein. Georgia Power will continue to monitor the
under recovered fuel cost balance in light of these higher fuel costs. See Note
3 to the financial statements of Georgia Power under &#147;Fuel Cost Recovery&#148; in
Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K for additional information.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><u>Storm Damage Cost Recovery</u>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">During the month of September&nbsp;2004, Georgia Power&#146;s service territory was
impacted by Hurricanes Frances, Ivan and Jeanne. Georgia Power maintains an
accumulated provision for property damage to cover the cost of damages from
major storms to its transmission and distribution lines and the cost of
uninsured damages to its generation facilities and other property as mandated
by the Georgia PSC. The total amount of damage related to these hurricanes was
estimated to be approximately $10&nbsp;million and was charged to the storm damage
reserve in September&nbsp;2004. These costs are expected to be recovered through
regular monthly accruals, which may be adjusted, if necessary, in connection
with Georgia Power&#146;s retail rate case. See &#147;Retail Rate Case&#148; herein for
additional information.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><I>Other Matters</I>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">On August&nbsp;12, 2004, Georgia Power and Gulf Power entered into a PPA with
Florida Power &#038; Light (FP&#038;L). Under the agreement, Georgia Power and Gulf Power
will provide FP&#038;L with 165 megawatts of capacity annually from the jointly
owned Plant Scherer Unit 3 for the period from June&nbsp;2010 through December&nbsp;2015.
The contract provides for fixed capacity payments and variable energy payments
based on actual energy delivered. The contract is contingent upon certain
events, including approval of the Florida PSC. The final outcome of this matter
cannot now be determined.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#150; RESULTS OF OPERATION &#150; &#147;Future
Earnings Potential &#150; Other Matters&#148; of Georgia Power in Item&nbsp;7 of the Form 10-K
for information on nuclear security measures. Georgia Power has implemented
plans for the measures ordered by the NRC to be in effect on October&nbsp;29, 2004
and is in compliance with the requirements. Georgia Power, based on its
ownership interest, currently estimates its expenditures related to these
security measures will total $9.8&nbsp;million, of which $1.4&nbsp;million will be
capitalized. These estimates are subject to change in the event additional NRC
guidance is provided.

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>GEORGIA POWER COMPANY</B><BR>

<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On October&nbsp;22, 2004, President Bush signed the American Jobs Creation Act
of 2004 (Jobs Act) into law. The Jobs Act represents the most significant
revision to the Internal Revenue Code since 1986. Congress must still develop
the regulations that will implement the requirements of the Jobs Act. Georgia
Power is currently assessing the impact of the Jobs Act on its taxable income.
However, Georgia Power currently does not expect the Jobs Act to have a
material impact on its financial statements.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Georgia Power is subject to certain claims and legal actions arising in
the ordinary course of business. In addition, Georgia Power&#146;s business
activities are subject to extensive governmental regulation related to public
health and the environment. Litigation over environmental issues and claims of
various types, including property damage, personal injury and citizen
enforcement of environmental requirements, has increased generally throughout
the United States. In particular, personal injury claims for damages caused by
alleged exposure to hazardous materials have become more frequent. The ultimate
outcome of such litigation against Georgia Power cannot be predicted at this
time; however, management does not anticipate that the liabilities, if any,
arising from such current proceedings would have a material adverse effect on
Georgia Power&#146;s financial statements.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;See the Notes to the Condensed Financial Statements herein for discussion
of various contingencies and other matters which may affect future earnings
potential.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>ACCOUNTING POLICIES</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Application of Critical Accounting Policies and Estimates</B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Georgia Power prepares its financial statements in accordance with accounting
principles generally accepted in the United States. Significant accounting
policies are described in Note 1 to the financial statements of Georgia Power
in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K. In the application of these policies, certain
estimates are made that may have
a material impact on Georgia Power&#146;s results of operations and related
disclosures. Different assumptions and
measurements could produce estimates that are significantly different from
those recorded in the financial statements. See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND
ANALYSIS &#151; ACCOUNTING POLICIES &#150; &#147;Application of Critical Accounting Policies
and Estimates&#148; of Georgia Power in Item&nbsp;7 of the Form 10-K for a complete
discussion of Georgia Power&#146;s critical accounting policies and estimates
related to Electric Utility Regulation and Contingent Obligations.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>New Accounting Standards</B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">On March&nbsp;31, 2004, Georgia Power prospectively adopted FASB Interpretation No.
46R, &#147;Consolidation of Variable Interest Entities,&#148; which requires the primary
beneficiary of a variable interest entity to consolidate the related assets and
liabilities. The adoption of FASB Interpretation No.&nbsp;46R had no impact on
Georgia Power&#146;s net income. However, as a result of the adoption, Georgia
Power deconsolidated certain wholly-owned trusts established to issue preferred
securities since Georgia Power does not meet the definition of primary
beneficiary established by FASB Interpretation No.&nbsp;46R. See Note (D)&nbsp;to the
Condensed Financial Statements herein for additional information related to the
adoption of FASB Interpretation No.&nbsp;46R.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In the third quarter 2004, Georgia Power prospectively adopted FASB Staff
Position (FSP)&nbsp;106-2, Accounting and Disclosure Requirements related to the
Medicare Prescription Drug, Improvement, and Modernization Act of 2003 (the
Medicare Act). The Medicare Act provides a 28% prescription drug subsidy for
Medicare eligible retirees. FSP&nbsp;106-2 requires recognition of the impacts of
the Medicare Act in the accumulated post-retirement benefit obligation (APBO)
and future cost of service for post-retirement medical

</DIV>
