<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">plans and may be applied retroactively to the enactment of the Medicare Act in
December&nbsp;2003 or prospectively effective for the third quarter 2004. Georgia
Power elected to apply this treatment prospectively. The effect of the subsidy
reduced Georgia Power&#146;s expenses for the three months ended September&nbsp;30, 2004
by approximately $2.3&nbsp;million and is expected to have a similar impact on
future expenses. The subsidy&#146;s impact on the post-retirement medical plan APBO
was a reduction of approximately $72&nbsp;million. However, the ultimate
impact on future periods is subject to federal regulations governing the
subsidy created in the Medicare Act being finalized. See Note (G)&nbsp;to the
Condensed Financial Statements herein for additional information.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>FINANCIAL CONDITION AND LIQUIDITY</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Overview</B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Major changes in Georgia Power&#146;s financial condition during the first nine months of 2004 included the addition
of approximately $856&nbsp;million to utility plant. The funds for these additions
and other capital requirements were derived primarily from operating activities
and equity funds from Southern Company. See Georgia Power&#146;s
Condensed Statements of Cash Flows herein for further details.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Capital Requirements and Contractual Obligations</B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#150; FINANCIAL CONDITION AND LIQUIDITY &#150;
&#147;Capital Requirements and Contractual Obligations&#148; of Georgia Power in Item&nbsp;7
of the Form 10-K for a description of Georgia Power&#146;s capital requirements for
its construction program, lease obligations, purchase commitments and trust
funding requirements. Approximately $302&nbsp;million will be required by September
30, 2005 for redemptions and maturities of long-term debt. The purchase of the
McIntosh construction project temporarily increased short-term borrowings under
the commercial paper program in the second quarter. The temporary increase was
replaced by long-term debt in the third quarter. See &#147;Financing Activities&#148;
herein for additional information. The projected construction program will
increase by $437.8&nbsp;million and $27.4&nbsp;million in 2004 and 2005, respectively,
for the McIntosh construction project and the projected purchased power
commitments will decrease by $133.2&nbsp;million in 2005-2006, $147.5&nbsp;million in
2007-2008 and $885.2&nbsp;million beyond 2008 as a result of the purchase of the
construction project.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Sources of Capital</B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Georgia Power plans to obtain the funds required for construction and other
purposes from sources similar to those used in the past, including funds from
operations and new security issuances. The amount, type and timing of
additional security issuances &#151; if needed &#151; will depend upon maintenance of
adequate earnings,
regulatory approval, prevailing market conditions and other factors. See
BUSINESS &#151; &#147;Financing Programs&#148; in Item&nbsp;1 of the Form 10-K for additional
information.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;At September&nbsp;30, 3004, Georgia Power&#146;s current liabilities exceeded
current assets as a result of $302&nbsp;million principal amount of
current maturities of long-term notes
and lease obligations. Georgia Power plans to
obtain the funds required for redemption from new security issuances. To meet
short-term cash needs and contingencies, Georgia Power had at September&nbsp;30,
2004 approximately $34&nbsp;million of cash and cash equivalents and $773&nbsp;million of
unused credit arrangements with banks. Of these facilities, $423&nbsp;million expire
in 2005 and contain provisions allowing two-year term loans executable at
expiration; and the remaining $350&nbsp;million expire in 2007. Georgia Power
expects to renew its credit facilities, as needed, prior to expiration. These
unused credit arrangements provide liquidity support to Georgia Power&#146;s
obligations with respect to variable rate pollution control bonds and
commercial paper. Georgia Power may also meet short-term cash needs through


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">57
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>GEORGIA POWER COMPANY</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
RESULTS OF OPERATIONS AND FINANCIAL CONDITION


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">a Southern Company subsidiary organized to issue and sell commercial paper and
extendible commercial notes at the request and for the benefit of Georgia Power
and other Southern Company subsidiaries. At September&nbsp;30, 2004, Georgia Power
had no commercial paper outstanding. Management believes that the need for
working capital can be adequately met by utilizing commercial paper programs
and lines of credit without maintaining large cash balances.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Credit Rating Risk</B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Georgia Power does not have any credit arrangements that would require material
changes in payment schedules or terminations as a result of a credit rating
downgrade. There are certain contracts that could require collateral, but not
accelerated payment, in the event of a credit rating change to below investment
grade. These contracts are primarily for physical electricity purchases and
sales, fixed-price physical gas purchases and agreements covering interest rate
swaps. At September&nbsp;30, 2004, the maximum potential collateral requirements
were approximately $228&nbsp;million. Generally, collateral may be provided for by a
Southern Company guaranty, letter of credit or cash.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Georgia Power is also party to certain derivative agreements that could
require collateral and/or accelerated payment in the event of a credit rating
change to below investment grade. These agreements are primarily for natural
gas price and interest rate risk management activities. At September&nbsp;30, 2004,
Georgia Power had no material exposure related to these agreements.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Market Price Risk</B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Georgia Power&#146;s market risk exposures relative to interest
rate changes have not changed materially compared with the December&nbsp;31, 2003
reporting period. In addition, Georgia Power is not aware of any facts or
circumstances that would significantly affect such exposures in the near term.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Due to cost-based rate regulations, Georgia Power has limited exposure to
market volatility in interest rates, commodity fuel prices and prices of
electricity. To mitigate residual risks relative to movements in electricity
prices, Georgia Power enters into fixed price contracts for the purchase and
sale of electricity through the wholesale electricity market and, to a lesser
extent, similar contracts for gas purchases. Georgia Power has also
implemented a retail fuel hedging program at the instruction of the Georgia
PSC.

follows:

<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;For additional information, see MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS -
FINANCIAL CONDITION AND LIQUIDITY  &#151; &#147;Market Price Risk&#148; of Georgia Power in
Item&nbsp;7 and Notes 1 and 6 to the financial statements of Georgia Power under
&#147;Financial Instruments&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K and Note (F)&nbsp;to the
Condensed Financial Statements herein.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Financing Activities</B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">In January&nbsp;2004, Georgia Power issued $100&nbsp;million of
Series&nbsp;S 4.00% Senior Notes due January&nbsp;15, 2011 and $100&nbsp;million of Series&nbsp;T
5.75% Senior Public Income Notes due January&nbsp;15, 2044. The proceeds from these
sales were used in March&nbsp;2004 to redeem all of its outstanding Series&nbsp;H 6.70%
Senior Insured Quarterly Notes due March&nbsp;1, 2011 and Series&nbsp;D 6 5/8% Senior
Notes due March&nbsp;31, 2039.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Further in January&nbsp;2004, Georgia Power Capital Trust VII, a statutory
trust, sold $200&nbsp;million of its 5 7/8% Trust Preferred Securities, which are
guaranteed by Georgia Power. The net proceeds from this issuance were used to
redeem the 6.85% Trust Preferred Securities of Georgia Power Capital Trust IV.
In connection with this transaction, Georgia Power issued $206&nbsp;million of its
junior subordinated debentures to Georgia Power Capital Trust VII.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In February&nbsp;2004, Georgia Power issued $150&nbsp;million of Series&nbsp;U Floating
Rate Senior Notes due February&nbsp;17, 2009. The proceeds of this sale were used
for general corporate purposes.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In August&nbsp;2004, Georgia Power issued $125&nbsp;million of Series&nbsp;V 4.10% Senior
Notes due August&nbsp;15, 2009 and $125&nbsp;million of Series&nbsp;W 6% Senior Notes due
August&nbsp;15, 2044. The proceeds from these sales were used to repay its
short-term indebtedness incurred in part to purchase the Plant McIntosh units
10 and 11 construction project and for its continuous construction program.
Upon the sale of the securities, interest rate swaps of $250&nbsp;million were
terminated at a loss of $12.1&nbsp;million. The loss from the terminated swaps was
deferred in Other Comprehensive Income and will be amortized to income over a
10-year period.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In addition to any financings that may be necessary to meet Georgia
Power&#146;s capital requirements and contractual obligations, Georgia Power plans
to continue, when economically feasible, a program to retire higher-cost debt
and replace these obligations with lower-cost capital if market conditions
permit.



<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">59
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>GULF POWER COMPANY</B><BR>
<DIV align="left">
<A name="128"></A>
</DIV>
<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
RESULTS OF OPERATIONS AND FINANCIAL CONDITION
</DIV>


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">THIRD QUARTER 2004 vs. THIRD QUARTER 2003<BR>
AND<BR>
YEAR-TO-DATE 2004 vs. YEAR-TO-DATE 2003



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>RESULTS OF OPERATIONS</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Earnings</B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Gulf Power&#146;s net income after dividends on preferred stock for the third
quarter and year-to-date 2004 was $31.9&nbsp;million and $67.7&nbsp;million,
respectively, compared to $32.8&nbsp;million and $65.6&nbsp;million, respectively, for
the corresponding periods in 2003. Earnings in the third quarter 2004 decreased
by $0.9&nbsp;million, or 2.7%, due to higher operating expenses and reduced revenues
as a result of outages from Hurricane Ivan. Earnings increased year-to-date
2004 by $2.2&nbsp;million, or 3.3%, primarily due to a reduction in interest expense
arising from refinancing of higher cost debt.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Significant income statement items appropriate for discussion include the
following:

<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Retail sales. </I>Excluding the recovery of fuel expense and certain other
expenses that do not affect net income, retail sales decreased by $0.4&nbsp;million,
or 0.3%, for the third quarter 2004 and increased by $4.5&nbsp;million, or 1.5%,
year-to-date 2004 when compared to the corresponding periods in 2003. Retail
sales revenues for the third quarter 2004 were lower than the corresponding
period in 2003 due primarily to the power outages resulting from Hurricane Ivan
in September&nbsp;2004. Approximately 90% of Gulf Power&#146;s 405,000 customers were
without electrical service immediately after the hurricane struck. Almost 72%
of those without power had service restored within one week, and two weeks
after the storm, power had been restored to all who could receive service.
Based on current projections, retail sales revenues lost as a result of the
power outages from Hurricane Ivan are not expected to have a material impact on
net income of Gulf Power for the year ending December&nbsp;31, 2004. For
year-to-date 2004, retail sales revenues were higher than the corresponding
period in 2003 primarily due to an increase in the number of customers and more
favorable weather in the first two quarters of 2004. During the third quarter
2004, retail energy sales to residential, commercial and industrial customers
decreased by 1.0%, 1.3% and 6.2%, respectively, as compared to the same period
in 2003. For year-to-date 2004 as compared to 2003, retail energy sales to
residential and commercial customers increased by


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">65
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>GULF POWER COMPANY</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
RESULTS OF OPERATIONS AND FINANCIAL CONDITION


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">1.0% and 1.5%, respectively, while energy sales to industrial customers
decreased by 3.2%. The decreases in industrial sales for the third quarter and
year-to-date 2004 are primarily the result of permanent load reductions and
customer operational issues, which vary from period to period.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Sales
for resale &#150; affiliates and Purchased power &#150; affiliates</I>. Revenues
from sales for resale to affiliates and purchases of energy from affiliates
will vary depending on demand and the availability and cost of generating
resources at each company within the Southern Company system. These
transactions do not have a significant impact on earnings since this energy is
generally sold at marginal cost and energy purchases are generally offset by
revenues through Gulf Power&#146;s fuel cost recovery mechanism. The increases in
the third quarter and year-to-date 2004 sales for resale to affiliates are due
to increased sales of available generation to affiliate companies at a higher
unit cost resulting from higher fuel prices. The increases in purchased power
from affiliates in the third quarter and year-to-date 2004 are primarily due to
higher fuel prices and an increase in capacity payments resulting from Gulf
Power&#146;s increased load growth.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Fuel expense. </I>During the third quarter 2004, fuel expense increased from
the corresponding period in 2003 primarily due to higher coal and natural gas
prices. The increase in fuel expense for year-to-date 2004 is primarily due to
a greater percentage of generation needs coming from higher priced natural gas
units and higher fuel prices. Since fuel expenses are generally offset by
revenues through Gulf Power&#146;s fuel cost recovery mechanism, these expenses do
not have a material impact on net income.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Purchased power &#150; non-affiliates. </I>The increases for the third quarter and
year-to-date 2004, when compared to the corresponding periods in 2003, are
primarily the result of power purchased from merchant generation resources in
order to minimize total production cost. Since energy expenses are generally
offset by revenues through Gulf Power&#146;s fuel cost recovery mechanism, these
expenses do not have a significant impact on net income.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Other operations expense. </I>The increase in other operations expense for
year-to-date 2004 when compared to the corresponding period in 2003 is
primarily due to a $3.5&nbsp;million increase in employee benefit expenses, a $1.5
million increase in expenses related to marketing conservation programs and a
$1.4&nbsp;million increase in accrued expenses for uninsured litigation and workers
compensation claims.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Maintenance expense. </I>The increases in maintenance expense during the
third quarter and year-to-date 2004 are due primarily to unscheduled plant
maintenance when compared to the corresponding periods in 2003.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Other income (expense), net. </I>The increases in this net expense for the
third quarter and year-to-date 2004 are primarily due to an increase in
charitable donations, when compared to the same periods in 2003<I>.</I>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Income taxes. </I>The decreases in income tax expense during the third
quarter and year-to-date 2004 are primarily due to a decrease in 2004 taxable
income resulting from a state tax credit for a charitable donation.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Future Earnings Potential</B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">The results of operations discussed above are not necessarily indicative of
future earnings potential. The level of future earnings depends on numerous
factors, including Gulf Power&#146;s ability to maintain a stable regulatory
environment, to achieve energy sales growth while containing costs and to
recover costs related to growing demand and increasingly stricter environmental
standards. Growth in energy sales is subject to a number of factors, which
include weather, competition, new energy contracts with neighboring utilities,
energy



<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">66
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">



<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>GULF POWER COMPANY</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
RESULTS OF OPERATIONS AND FINANCIAL CONDITION


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">conservation practiced by customers, the price of electricity, the price
elasticity of demand and the rate of economic growth in Gulf Power&#146;s service
area. For additional information relating to these issues, see BUSINESS &#151; The
SOUTHERN System &#151; &#147;Risk Factors&#148; in Item&nbsp;1 and MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND
ANALYSIS &#150; RESULTS OF OPERATIONS &#151; &#147;Future Earnings Potential&#148; of Gulf Power in
Item&nbsp;7 of the Form 10-K.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><I>Environmental Matters</I>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><U>New Source Review
Actions</U>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Compliance costs related to the Clean Air Act and other environmental
regulations could affect earnings if such costs are not fully recovered through
Gulf Power&#146;s Environmental Cost Recovery Clause. See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION
AND ANALYSIS &#150; RESULTS OF OPERATIONS &#150; &#147;Future Earnings Potential -
Environmental Matters&#148; of Gulf Power in Item&nbsp;7 and Note 3 to the financial
statements of Gulf Power under &#147;New Source Review Actions&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the
Form 10-K. As of March&nbsp;15, 2004, civil penalties under the Clean Air Act were
increased prospectively to a maximum of $32,500 per day, per violation. To the
extent alleged violations under the New Source Review litigation are deemed to
be continuing, this increased civil penalty amount could apply to such
violations found to continue after that date.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On May&nbsp;3, 2004, the U.S. Supreme Court denied the EPA&#146;s petition to review
the Eleventh Circuit Court of Appeals&#146; decision in the EPA&#146;s similar New Source
Review enforcement action against the TVA. With the denial of the EPA&#146;s
petition for review, the Court of Appeals&#146; decision is now final. An adverse
outcome in the New Source Review litigation described in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form
10-K could require substantial capital expenditures and could possibly require
payment of substantial penalties that cannot be determined at this time. This
could affect future results of operations, cash flows and possibly financial
condition if such costs are not recovered through regulated rates.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><u>Global Warming
Litigation</U>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">On July&nbsp;21, 2004, attorneys general from eight states, each outside of Southern
Company&#146;s service territory, and the corporation counsel for New York City
filed a complaint in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New
York against Southern Company and four other electric power companies. A
nearly identical complaint was filed by three environmental groups in the same
court. The complaints allege that the companies&#146; emissions of carbon dioxide, a
greenhouse gas, contribute to global warming, which the plaintiffs assert is a
public nuisance. Plaintiffs seek relief under the federal common law or, in the
alternative, under state law, of public nuisance. The environmental groups
also seek relief under common law private nuisance theories. The plaintiffs
seek a judicial order (1)&nbsp;holding each defendant jointly and severally liable
for creating, contributing to, and/or maintaining an ongoing public nuisance,
global warming and (2)&nbsp;permanently enjoining each of the defendants to abate
its contribution to the nuisance by capping its emissions of carbon dioxide and
then reducing those emissions by a specified percentage each year for at least
a decade. Plaintiffs have not, however, requested that damages be awarded in
connection with their claims. Southern Company believes these claims are
without merit and notes that the complaint cites no statutory or regulatory
basis for the claims. Southern Company and the other defendants have filed
motions to dismiss both lawsuits. Southern Company intends to vigorously defend
against these claims. While the outcome of this matter cannot be determined at
this time, an adverse judgment could result in substantial capital
expenditures.



<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">67
</DIV>


<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">



<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>GULF POWER COMPANY</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
RESULTS OF OPERATIONS AND FINANCIAL CONDITION



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><U>Other Environmental
Matters</U>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">On May&nbsp;5, 2004, the EPA published proposed amendments to its Regional Haze
rules with respect to Best Available Retrofit Technology guidelines and
requirements. The impact of these regulations will depend on the development
and implementation of the final rules and implementation by the states, and
therefore cannot be determined at this time.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#150; &#147;Future Earnings Potential -
Environmental Matters &#150; Environmental Statutes and Regulations&#148; of Gulf Power
in Item&nbsp;7 and Note 3 to the financial statements of Gulf Power under
&#147;Environmental Cost Recovery&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K and Note (O)&nbsp;to the
Condensed Financial Statements herein for information on liabilities associated
with environmental remediation projects. During the third quarter 2004, Gulf
Power increased its estimated liability for these projects by approximately $47
million as a result of revised rules and changes in the extent of remediation
expected to be required by the Florida Department of Environmental Protection
(FDEP). The majority of the remediation areas are active substation sites. The
schedule for completion of the remediation projects will be subject to FDEP
approval. The projects have been approved by the Florida PSC for recovery, as
expended, through Gulf Power&#146;s environmental cost recovery clause; therefore,
there was no impact on Gulf Power&#146;s net income as a result of these revised
estimates.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><I>FERC and Florida PSC Matters</I>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><U>Market-Based Rate
Authority</U>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#150; RESULTS OF OPERATIONS &#150; &#147;Future
Earnings Potential &#150; FERC Matters &#150; Market Based Rate Authority&#148; of Gulf Power
in Item&nbsp;7 and Note 3 to the financial statements of Gulf Power under &#147;FERC
Matters&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K. On April&nbsp;14, 2004, the FERC issued an
order that abandoned the SMA test and adopted a new interim analysis for
measuring generation market power. This new interim approach requires utilities
to submit a pivotal supplier analysis and a wholesale market share analysis,
the results of which provide a rebuttable presumption regarding generation
market power. The FERC&#146;s order also sets forth procedures for rebutting these
presumptions and addresses mitigation measures for those entities that are
found to have market power. In the absence of specific mitigation measures,
the order includes several cost-based mitigation measures that would apply by
default. The FERC also initiated a new rulemaking proceeding that, among other
things, will adopt a final methodology for assessing generation market power.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On July&nbsp;8, 2004, the FERC denied Southern Company&#146;s request for rehearing,
along with a number of others, and reaffirmed the interim tests that it adopted
in April. Southern Company submitted the required analyses on August&nbsp;9, 2004.
In that filing, Southern Company passed the pivotal supplier analysis for all
markets and the wholesale market share analysis for all markets except the
Southern Company control area. Southern Company also submitted other analyses
to demonstrate that it lacks generation market power. This filing remains
pending at the FERC. Southern Company, along with other utilities, has also
filed an appeal of the FERC&#146;s April&nbsp;14, 2004 order with the Circuit Court of
Appeals in Washington, D.C. In the event that the FERC&#146;s default mitigation
measures are ultimately applied, Gulf Power may be required to charge
cost-based rates for certain wholesale sales, which may be lower than
negotiated market-based rates. The final outcome of this matter will depend on
the form in which the final methodology for assessing generation market power
and mitigation rules may be ultimately adopted and cannot be determined at this
time.


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">68
</DIV>


<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>GULF POWER COMPANY</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
RESULTS OF OPERATIONS AND FINANCIAL CONDITION



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><U>Transmission</U>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#150; RESULTS OF OPERATIONS &#150; &#147;Future
Earnings Potential &#150; FERC Matters &#150; Transmission&#148; of Gulf Power in Item&nbsp;7 of
the Form 10-K for information on the
FERC&#146;s order related to RTOs and notice of proposed rulemaking regarding open
access transmission service and standard electricity market design.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><U>Storm Damage Cost
Recovery</U>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">On September&nbsp;15 and 16, 2004, Hurricane Ivan hit the Gulf Coast of Florida and
Alabama causing substantial damage in Gulf Power&#146;s service territory. Gulf
Power maintains an accumulated provision for property damage to cover the cost
of damages from major storms to its transmission and distribution lines and the
cost of uninsured damages to its generation facilities and other property.
Prior to Hurricane Ivan, the balance in the accumulated provision for property
damage was approximately $28&nbsp;million. The estimated total amount of damage
related to Hurricane Ivan charged to the accumulated provision for property
damage as of September&nbsp;2004 was $75.5&nbsp;million. Gulf Power&#146;s current annual
accrual to the accumulated provision for property damage, as approved by the
Florida PSC, is $3.5&nbsp;million. The Florida PSC has also approved
additional accrual amounts at Gulf Power&#146;s discretion. Gulf Power is currently
reviewing alternatives that would potentially allow for more rapid recovery of
these costs. See Note 1 to Gulf Power&#146;s financial statements under &#147;Provision
for Property Damage&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K for additional information.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><I>Other Matters</I>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">On August&nbsp;12, 2004, Georgia Power and Gulf Power entered into a PPA with
Florida Power &#038; Light (FP&#038;L). Under the agreement, Georgia Power and Gulf Power
will provide FP&#038;L with 165 megawatts of capacity annually from the jointly
owned Plant Scherer Unit 3 for the period from June&nbsp;2010 through December&nbsp;2015.
The contract provides for fixed capacity payments and variable energy payments
based on actual energy delivered. The contract is contingent upon certain
events, including approval of the Florida PSC. The final outcome of this matter
cannot now be determined.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On October&nbsp;22, 2004, President Bush signed the American Jobs Creation Act
of 2004 (the Jobs Act) into law. The Jobs Act represents the most significant
revision to the Internal Revenue Code since 1986. Congress must still develop
the regulations that will implement the requirements of the Jobs Act. Gulf
Power is currently assessing the impact of the Jobs Act on its taxable income.
However, Gulf Power currently does not expect the Jobs Act to have a material
impact on its financial statements.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Gulf Power is subject to certain claims and legal actions arising in the
ordinary course of business. In addition, Gulf Power&#146;s business activities are
subject to extensive governmental regulation related to public health and the
environment. Litigation over environmental issues and claims of various types,
including property damage, personal injury and citizen enforcement of
environmental requirements, has increased
generally throughout the United States. In particular, personal injury claims
for damages caused by alleged exposure to hazardous materials have become more
frequent. The ultimate outcome of such litigation against Gulf Power cannot be
predicted at this time; however, management does not anticipate that the
liabilities, if any, arising from such current proceedings would have a material adverse effect
on Gulf Power&#146;s financial statements.


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">69
</DIV>

<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>ACCOUNTING POLICIES</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Application of Critical Accounting Policies and Estimates</B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Gulf Power prepares its financial statements in accordance with accounting
principles generally accepted in the United States. Significant accounting
policies are described in Note 1 to the financial statements of Gulf Power in
Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K. In the application of these policies, certain
estimates are made that may have a material impact on Gulf Power&#146;s results of
operations and related disclosures. Different assumptions and measurements
could produce estimates that are significantly different from those recorded in
the financial statements. See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS -
ACCOUNTING POLICIES &#150; &#147;Application of Critical Accounting Policies and
Estimates&#148; of Gulf Power in Item&nbsp;7 of the Form 10-K for a
complete discussion of Gulf Power&#146;s critical accounting policies and estimates
related to Electric Utility Regulation and Contingent Obligations.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>New Accounting Standards</B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">On March&nbsp;31, 2004, Gulf Power prospectively adopted FASB Interpretation No.
46R, &#147;Consolidation of Variable Interest Entities,&#148; which requires the primary
beneficiary of a variable interest entity to consolidate the related assets and
liabilities. The adoption of FASB Interpretation No.&nbsp;46R had no impact on Gulf
Power&#146;s net income. However, as a result of the adoption, Gulf Power
deconsolidated certain wholly-owned trusts established to issue preferred
securities since Gulf Power does not meet the definition of primary beneficiary
established by FASB Interpretation No.&nbsp;46R. See Note (D)&nbsp;to the Condensed
Financial Statements herein for additional information related to the adoption
of FASB Interpretation No.&nbsp;46R.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In the third quarter 2004, Gulf Power prospectively adopted FASB Staff
Position (FSP)&nbsp;106-2, Accounting and Disclosure Requirements related to the
Medicare Prescription Drug, Improvement, and Modernization Act of 2003 (the
Medicare Act). The Medicare Act provides a 28% prescription drug subsidy for
Medicare eligible retirees. FSP 106-2 requires recognition of the impacts of
the Medicare Act in the accumulated post-retirement
benefit obligation (APBO)&nbsp;and future cost of service for post-retirement
medical plans and may be applied retroactively to the enactment of the Medicare
Act in December&nbsp;2003 or prospectively effective for the third quarter 2004.
Gulf Power elected to apply this treatment prospectively. The effect of the
subsidy reduced Gulf Power&#146;s expenses for the three months ended September&nbsp;30,
2004 by approximately $0.2&nbsp;million and is expected to have a similar impact on
future expenses. The subsidy&#146;s impact on the post-retirement medical plan APBO
was a reduction of approximately $8&nbsp;million. However, the ultimate impact on
future periods is subject to federal regulations governing the subsidy created
in the Medicare Act being finalized. See Note (G)&nbsp;to the Condensed Financial
Statements herein for additional information.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>FINANCIAL CONDITION AND LIQUIDITY</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Overview</B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Major changes in Gulf Power&#146;s financial condition during the first nine months
of 2004 included the addition of approximately $106.7&nbsp;million to utility plant.
The funds for these additions and other capital requirements were
derived primarily from operating activities. See Gulf Power&#146;s Condensed
Statements of Cash Flows herein for further details.

</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->

<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">



<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>GULF POWER COMPANY</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
RESULTS OF OPERATIONS AND FINANCIAL CONDITION



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Capital Requirements and Contractual Obligations</B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Reference is made to MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#150; FINANCIAL CONDITION
AND LIQUIDITY &#150; &#147;Capital Requirements and Contractual Obligations&#148; of Gulf
Power in Item&nbsp;7 of the Form 10-K for a description of Gulf Power&#146;s capital requirements for its construction
program, lease obligations, purchase commitments and trust funding
requirements. Approximately $75&nbsp;million will be required by September&nbsp;30, 2005
for redemptions and maturities of long-term debt.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Sources of Capital</B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">In addition to the financing activities described herein, Gulf Power plans to
obtain the funds required for construction and other purposes from sources
similar to those used in the past. These sources include cash
flows from operating activities and issuances of unsecured debt, trust
preferred securities, preferred stock and pollution control bonds issued for
Gulf Power&#146;s benefit by public authorities. The amount, type and timing of any
future financings, if needed, will depend upon market conditions and regulatory
approval. See BUSINESS &#150; &#147;Financing Programs&#148; in Item&nbsp;1 of the Form 10-K for
additional information.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;At
September&nbsp;30, 2004, Gulf Power&#146;s current liabilities exceeded current
assets as a result of the scheduled redemption of $75&nbsp;million principal amount
of 6.10% senior notes, originally due in 2016. These notes were redeemed in
October&nbsp;2004 with proceeds from the Series&nbsp;K 4.90% Senior
Notes due October&nbsp;1, 2014 that
were issued in September. See &#147;Financing Activities&#148; herein for additional
information. To meet short-term cash needs and contingencies, Gulf Power has
various internal and external sources of liquidity. In addition, Gulf Power has
substantial cash flow from operating activities. At September&nbsp;30, 2004, Gulf
Power had approximately $46.4&nbsp;million of cash and cash
equivalents and $56.5
million of unused committed lines of credit with banks which expire in 2005.
Gulf Power expects to renew its credit facilities, as needed, prior to
expiration. The credit arrangements provide liquidity support to Gulf Power&#146;s
obligations with respect to variable rate pollution control bonds and
commercial paper. Gulf Power may also meet short-term cash needs through a
Southern Company subsidiary organized to issue and sell commercial paper and
extendible commercial notes at the request and for the benefit of Gulf Power
and other Southern Company subsidiaries. At September&nbsp;30, 2004, Gulf Power had
no commercial paper outstanding. Subsequent to September&nbsp;30, 2004, Gulf Power
entered into loan agreements for $50&nbsp;million maturing October&nbsp;21, 2005 and $100
million maturing October&nbsp;28, 2005. Proceeds from these borrowings were used for
general corporate purposes and to finance repairs to Gulf Power&#146;s electric
system for damage suffered as a result of Hurricane Ivan. Management believes
that the need for working capital can be adequately met by utilizing lines of
credit, commercial paper and bank notes without maintaining large cash
balances.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Credit Rating Risk</B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Gulf Power does not have any credit arrangements that would require material
changes in payment schedules or terminations as a result of a credit rating
downgrade. Gulf Power is party to certain derivative agreements that could
require collateral and/or accelerated payment in the event of a credit rating
change to below investment grade. These agreements are primarily for natural gas price risk management
activities. At September&nbsp;30, 2004, Gulf Power had no material exposure related
to these agreements.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Market Price Risk</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Gulf Power&#146;s market risk exposures relative to interest rate changes have not
changed materially compared with the December&nbsp;31, 2003 reporting period. In
addition, Gulf Power is not aware of any facts or circumstances


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">71
</DIV>

<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">that would significantly affect such exposures in the near term.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Due to cost-based rate regulations, Gulf Power has limited exposure to
market volatility in interest rates, commodity fuel prices and prices of
electricity. To mitigate residual risks relative to movements in electricity
prices, Gulf Power enters into fixed price contracts for the purchase of coal
supplies, the purchase and sale of electricity through the wholesale
electricity market and, to a lesser extent, similar contracts for gas
purchases. Gulf Power has received approval from the Florida PSC to recover prudently
incurred costs related to its fuel hedging program through the fuel cost
recovery mechanism. The fair value of derivative energy contracts at September
30, 2004 was as follows:

<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;See
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#150; FINANCIAL CONDITION AND
LIQUIDITY &#150; &#147;Market Price Risk&#148; of Gulf Power in Item&nbsp;7 of the Form 10-K and
Notes 1 and 6 to the financial statements of Gulf Power under &#147;Financial Instruments&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K and Note
(F)&nbsp;to the Condensed Financial Statements herein for further information.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Financing Activities</B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">In April&nbsp;2004, Gulf Power issued $35&nbsp;million of Series&nbsp;J 5.875% Senior Notes
due April&nbsp;1, 2044. The proceeds from this issue were used for general corporate
purposes, including Gulf Power&#146;s continuous construction program.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In September&nbsp;2004, Gulf Power issued $75&nbsp;million of Series&nbsp;K 4.90% Senior
Notes due October&nbsp;1, 2014. The proceeds from this issue were used to redeem the
$75&nbsp;million outstanding principle amount of its Series&nbsp;D 6.10% Senior Notes on
October&nbsp;22, 2004.


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">72
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>GULF POWER COMPANY</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
RESULTS OF OPERATIONS AND FINANCIAL CONDITION



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Subsequent to September&nbsp;30, 2004, Gulf Power entered into loan agreements
for $50&nbsp;million maturing October&nbsp;21, 2005 and $100&nbsp;million maturing October&nbsp;28,
2005. Proceeds from these borrowings were used for general corporate purposes
and to finance repairs to Gulf Power&#146;s electric system for damage suffered as a result
of Hurricane Ivan.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In addition to any financings that may be necessary to meet Gulf Power&#146;s
capital requirements and contractual obligations, Gulf Power plans to continue,
when economically feasible, a program to retire higher-cost debt and replace
these obligations with lower-cost capital if market conditions permit.



<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">73
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">78

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>MISSISSIPPI POWER COMPANY</B><BR>
<DIV align="left">
<A name="134"></A>
</DIV>
<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
RESULTS OF OPERATIONS AND FINANCIAL CONDITION
</DIV>


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">THIRD QUARTER 2004 vs. THIRD QUARTER 2003<BR>
AND<BR>
YEAR-TO-DATE 2004 vs. YEAR-TO-DATE 2003



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>RESULTS OF OPERATIONS</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Earnings</B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Mississippi Power&#146;s net income after dividends on preferred stock for the third
quarter and year-to-date 2004 was $35.6&nbsp;million and $74.8&nbsp;million,
respectively, compared to $34.4&nbsp;million and $108.8&nbsp;million, respectively, for
the corresponding periods of 2003. Earnings for year-to-date 2004 decreased
$34&nbsp;million, or 31.3%, primarily as a result of the 2003 gain of $38&nbsp;million
after tax related to the termination of a PPA with Dynegy and related 2003
contract revenue of $10&nbsp;million after-tax. This decrease was partially offset
by the net impact of a $6&nbsp;million after tax decrease in other operations
expense related to costs incurred in the third quarter of 2003 to restructure
the lease agreement for the combined cycle generating units at Plant Daniel and
a decrease of $8&nbsp;million after tax in depreciation and amortization resulting
from the impact of the Mississippi PSC&#146;s order approving the inclusion of the
additional Plant Daniel capacity in jurisdictional cost of service. See Note 3
to the financial statements of Mississippi Power under &#147;Contract Termination&#148;
and &#147;Retail Regulatory Filing&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K and Note (K)&nbsp;to the
Condensed Financial Statements herein for additional information.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Significant income statement items appropriate for discussion include the
following:

<DIV align="center">
<TABLE style="font-size: 10pt" cellspacing="0" border="0" cellpadding="0" width="75%">
<!-- Begin Table Head -->
<TR valign="bottom">
    <TD width="36%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="7%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="7%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="7%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="7%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="7%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="7%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="7%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="7%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>
<TR style="font-size: 8pt" valign="bottom">

</DIV>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Retail sales. </I>Retail sales revenue increased $16.9&nbsp;million, or 11.2%, in
the third quarter 2004 and $49.3&nbsp;million or 12.4% year-to-date 2004 when
compared to the same periods in 2003. The increases in retail sales revenues
are primarily the result of increases of $15.3&nbsp;million in the third quarter
2004 and $47.6&nbsp;million year-to-date 2004 in fuel cost recovery revenues, which
generally do not have an effect on income. Retail sales revenues, excluding
fuel revenues, for the third quarter 2004 to residential and commercial
customers remained mostly constant while retail sales to industrial customers,
excluding fuel revenues, decreased 2.2% primarily as a result
of the effects Hurricane Ivan when compared to the same period in 2003. Retail
sales revenues, excluding fuel revenues, for year-to-date 2004 from
residential, commercial and industrial customers


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">79
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>MISSISSIPPI POWER COMPANY</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
RESULTS OF OPERATIONS AND FINANCIAL CONDITION


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">remained mostly constant as compared to the same period in 2003.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Sales
for resale &#151; non-affiliates. </I>The increases in sales for resale to
non-affiliates in the third quarter and year-to-date 2004 as compared to the
same periods in 2003 are primarily due to the increases of $6.6&nbsp;million and
$13.3&nbsp;million, respectively, in revenue from wholesale territorial customers
that were offset by decreases of $1.9&nbsp;million and $3.7&nbsp;million, respectively,
in revenue from non-territorial customers. The increases in the third quarter
and year-to-date 2004 revenue from wholesale territorial customers as compared
to the same periods in 2003 are the result of increases in the price per
kilowatt-hour due to fuel cost. The decreases in the third quarter and year to
date 2004 revenue from wholesale non-territorial customers as compared to the
same period in 2003 are the result of the loss of capacity revenues as a result
of the termination of the Dynegy contract in 2003.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Sales for resale &#151; affiliates and Purchased power &#151; affiliates</I>. Revenues
from sales for resale to affiliates, as well as purchases of energy from
affiliates, will vary depending on demand and the availability and cost of
generating resources at each company within the Southern Company system. These
transactions do not have a significant impact on earnings since the energy is
generally sold at marginal cost and energy purchases are generally offset by
energy revenues through Mississippi Power&#146;s retail and wholesale fuel cost
recovery clauses. The increase in sales for resale to affiliates is primarily
a result of more generation available for sale. The increase in purchased power
from affiliates is primarily due to the increase in the cost of fuel.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Fuel expense. </I>In the third quarter and year-to-date 2004, fuel expense
increased when compared to the same periods in 2003 as a result of 10.5% and
10.3% increases in generation, respectively, and 20.4% and 29.0% increases in
the cost of gas, respectively. Since energy expenses are generally offset by
energy revenues through Mississippi Power&#146;s retail and wholesale fuel cost
recovery clauses, these expenses do not have a significant impact on earnings.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Purchased
power &#151; non-affiliates</I>. The third quarter and year-to-date 2004
purchased power from non-affiliates increased due to higher fuel prices in
2004.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Other operations expense. </I>The third quarter and year-to-date 2004
decreases in other operations expense when compared to the same periods in 2003
are a result of approximately $11&nbsp;million incurred during the third quarter
2003 to restructure the lease agreement for the combined cycle generating units
at Plant Daniel. See Note 7 to the financial statements of Mississippi Power
under &#147;Operating Leases &#151; Plant Daniel Combined Cycle Generating Units&#148; in Item
8 of the Form 10-K for additional information.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Maintenance expense. </I>The third quarter and year-to-date 2004 increases in
maintenance expense when compared to the same periods in 2003 are primarily a
result of higher operating hours at the combined cycle units in 2004 and
resulting higher expense. See Note 7 to the financial statements of Mississippi
Power under &#147;Long-Term Service Agreements&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K for
additional information.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Depreciation and amortization. </I>The third quarter and year-to-date 2004
decreases in depreciation and amortization expense when compared to the same
periods in 2003 are primarily the result of the amortization of a regulatory
liability as approved by the Mississippi PSC. The Mississippi PSC issued an
interim accounting order in December&nbsp;2003 directing Mississippi Power to
expense and record in 2003 a regulatory liability in the amount of
approximately $60&nbsp;million. Mississippi Power recorded a credit to expense in
the amount of $4.1&nbsp;million and $12.4&nbsp;million for the quarter and year-to-date
2004, respectively, to amortize this regulatory liability retroactive
to January&nbsp;1, 2004. See Note 3 to the financial statements of Mississippi
Power under &#147;Retail Regulatory Filing&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K and &#147;Future
Earnings Potential &#151; FERC and Mississippi


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">80
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>MISSISSIPPI POWER COMPANY</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
RESULTS OF OPERATIONS AND FINANCIAL CONDITION


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">PSC Matters &#151; Retail Rate Filing&#148; and Note (K)&nbsp;to the Condensed Financial
Statements herein for additional information.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Interest expense. </I>The decreases in interest expense for the third quarter
and year-to-date 2004 as compared to the same periods in 2003 are a result of
lower interest rates. See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND
ANALYSIS &#151; FINANCIAL CONDITION AND LIQUIDITY &#151; &#147;Financing Activities&#148; of
Mississippi Power in Item&nbsp;7 of the Form 10-K and FINANCIAL CONDITION AND
LIQUIDITY &#151; &#147;Financing Activities&#148; herein for further information on efforts to
reduce interest rates.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Other income (expense), net. </I>The third quarter and year-to-date 2004
decreases in other income (expense), net of $2&nbsp;million, or 93.8%, and $2.4
million, or 82.4%, respectively, are the result of lower revenue from
miscellaneous contract work and a FERC settlement in July&nbsp;2003 that resulted in
the recognition, in the third quarter 2003, of $1.2&nbsp;million of revenue
previously reserved for refund. See Note 3 to the financial statements of
Mississippi Power under &#147;Transmission Facilities Agreement&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the
Form 10-K.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Income taxes. </I>The third quarter and year-to-date 2004 income taxes
increased $0.6&nbsp;million, or 2.6%, and decreased $20.1&nbsp;million, or 29.5%,
respectively, as a direct result of the changes in earnings before income taxes
when compared to the same periods in 2003.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Dividends on preferred stock. </I>The year-to-date 2004 increase in dividends
on preferred stock is the result of a $2.0&nbsp;million loss on the redemption of
preferred stock recognized in the second quarter of 2004. The third quarter
2004 dividends on preferred stock remained fairly constant in comparison to the
same period in 2003.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Future Earnings Potential</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">The results of operations discussed above are not necessarily indicative of
future earnings potential. The level of future earnings depends on numerous
factors including Mississippi Power&#146;s ability to maintain a stable regulatory
environment, to achieve energy sales growth while containing costs and to
recover costs related to growing demand and increasingly stricter environmental
standards. Growth in energy sales is subject to a number of factors, which
include weather, competition, new energy contracts with neighboring utilities,
energy conservation practiced by customers, the price of electricity, the price
elasticity of demand and the rate of economic growth in Mississippi Power&#146;s
service area. For additional information relating to these issues, see
BUSINESS &#151; The SOUTHERN System &#151; &#147;Risk Factors&#148; in Item&nbsp;1 and MANAGEMENT&#146;S
DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#151; RESULTS OF OPERATIONS &#151; &#147;Future Earnings Potential&#148;
of Mississippi Power in Item&nbsp;7 in the Form 10-K.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><I>Environmental Matters</I>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><U>New Source Review
Actions</U>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Mississippi Power&#146;s 2004 ECO Plan filing was approved, as filed, by the
Mississippi PSC on March&nbsp;15, 2004, and resulted in a slight decrease in rates
effective April&nbsp;2004. Compliance costs related to the Clean Air Act and other
environmental regulations could affect earnings if such costs cannot continue
to be recovered. See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#151; RESULTS OF
OPERATIONS &#151; &#147;Future Earnings Potential &#151; Environmental Matters&#148; of Mississippi
Power in Item&nbsp;7 and Note 3 to the financial statements of
Mississippi Power under &#147;New Source Review Actions&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K.
As of March&nbsp;15, 2004, civil penalties under the Clean Air Act were increased
prospectively to a maximum of $32,500 per day, per



<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">81
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">



<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>MISSISSIPPI POWER COMPANY</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
RESULTS OF OPERATIONS AND FINANCIAL CONDITION


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">violation. To the extent alleged violations under the New Source Review
litigation are deemed to be continuing, this increased civil penalty amount
could apply to such violations found to continue after that date.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On May&nbsp;3, 2004, the U.S. Supreme Court denied the EPA&#146;s petition to review
the Eleventh Circuit Court of Appeals&#146; decision in the EPA&#146;s similar New Source
Review action against the TVA. With the denial of the EPA&#146;s petition for
review, the Court of Appeals&#146; decision is now final. An adverse outcome in the
New Source Review litigation described in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K could require
substantial capital expenditures and could possibly require payment of
substantial penalties that cannot be determined at this time. This could
affect future results of operations, cash flows and possibly financial
condition if such costs are not recovered through regulated rates.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><U>Global Warming
Litigation</U>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">On July&nbsp;21, 2004, attorneys general from eight states, each outside of Southern
Company&#146;s service territory, and the corporation counsel for New York City
filed a complaint in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New
York against Southern Company and four other electric power companies. A
nearly identical complaint was filed by three environmental groups in the same
court. The complaints allege that the companies&#146; emissions of carbon dioxide, a
greenhouse gas, contribute to global warming, which the plaintiffs assert is a
public nuisance. Plaintiffs seek relief under the federal common law or, in the
alternative, under state law, of public nuisance. The environmental groups
also seek relief under common law private nuisance theories. The plaintiffs
seek a judicial order (1)&nbsp;holding each defendant jointly and severally liable
for creating, contributing to, and/or maintaining an ongoing public nuisance,
global warming and (2)&nbsp;permanently enjoining each of the defendants to abate
its contribution to the nuisance by capping its emissions of carbon dioxide and
then reducing those emissions by a specified percentage each year for at least
a decade. Plaintiffs have not, however, requested that damages be awarded in
connection with their claims. Southern Company believes these claims are
without merit and notes that the complaint cites no statutory or regulatory
basis for the claims. Southern Company and the other defendants have filed
motions to dismiss both lawsuits. Southern Company intends to vigorously defend
against these claims. While the outcome of this matter cannot be determined at
this time, an adverse judgment could result in substantial capital
expenditures.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><U>Other Environmental
Matters</U>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">On May&nbsp;5, 2004, the EPA published proposed amendments to its Regional Haze
rules with respect to Best Available Retrofit Technology guidelines and
requirements. The impact of these regulations will depend on the development
and implementation of the final rules and implementation by the states, and
therefore cannot be determined at this time.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><I>FERC and Mississippi PSC Matters</I>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><U>Market-Based Rate
Authority</U>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#151; RESULTS OF OPERATIONS &#151; &#147;Future
Earnings Potential &#151; FERC Matters &#151; Market-Based Rate Authority&#148; of Mississippi
Power in Item&nbsp;7 and Note 3 to the financial statements of Mississippi Power
under &#147;FERC Matters&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K. On April&nbsp;14, 2004, the FERC
issued an order that abandoned the SMA test and adopted a new interim analysis
for measuring
generation market power. This new interim approach requires utilities to
submit a pivotal supplier analysis and a wholesale market share analysis, the
results of which provide a rebuttable presumption regarding generation market
power. The FERC&#146;s order also sets forth procedures for rebutting these
presumptions and addresses



<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">82
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">



<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>MISSISSIPPI POWER COMPANY</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
RESULTS OF OPERATIONS AND FINANCIAL CONDITION


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">mitigation measures for those entities that are found to have market power. In
the absence of specific mitigation measures, the order includes several
cost-based mitigation measures that would apply by default.
The FERC also initiated a new rulemaking proceeding that, among other things,
will adopt a final methodology for assessing generation market power.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On July&nbsp;8, 2004, the FERC denied Southern Company&#146;s request for rehearing,
along with a number of others, and reaffirmed the interim tests that it adopted
in April. Southern Company submitted the required analyses on August&nbsp;9, 2004.
In that filing, Southern Company passed the pivotal supplier analysis for all
markets and the wholesale market share analysis for all markets except the
Southern Company control area. Southern Company also submitted other analyses
to demonstrate that it lacks generation market power. This filing remains
pending at the FERC. Southern Company, along with other utilities, has also
filed an appeal of the FERC&#146;s April&nbsp;14, 2004 order with the Circuit Court of
Appeals in Washington, D.C. In the event that the FERC&#146;s default mitigation
measures are ultimately applied, Mississippi Power may be required to charge
cost-based rates for certain wholesale sales, which may be lower than
negotiated market-based rates. The final outcome of this matter will depend on
the form in which the final methodology for assessing generation market power
and mitigation rules may be ultimately adopted and cannot be determined at this
time. See Note (B)&nbsp;to the Condensed Financial Statements under &#147;FERC Matters&#148;
herein for additional information.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><u>Transmission</u>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#151;  RESULTS OF OPERATIONS &#151; &#147;Future
Earnings Potential &#151; FERC Matters &#151; Transmission&#148; of Mississippi Power in Item
7 of the Form 10-K for information on the FERC&#146;s order related to RTOs and the
notice of proposed rulemaking regarding open access transmission service and
standard electricity market design.

<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><u>Retail Rate Filing</u>

<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">On December&nbsp;5, 2003, Mississippi
Power filed a request with the Mississippi PSC
to reclassify 266 megawatts
of Plant Daniel Units 3 and 4 generating capacity not currently included in
jurisdictional cost of service. As part of Mississippi Power&#146;s proposal to
include the additional Plant Daniel capacity in retail rates, the Mississippi
PSC issued an interim accounting order in December&nbsp;2003 directing Mississippi
Power to expense and record in 2003 a regulatory liability in the amount of
approximately $60&nbsp;million while the Mississippi PSC fully considered the entire
request. On May&nbsp;25, 2004, the Mississippi PSC issued an order related to this
matter. The Mississippi PSC approved Mississippi Power&#146;s request to reclassify
the 266 megawatts of Plant Daniel unit 3 and 4 capacity to jurisdictional cost
of service effective January&nbsp;1, 2004 and authorized Mississippi Power to
include the related costs and revenue credits in jurisdictional rate base, cost
of service and revenue requirement calculations for purposes of retail rate
recovery. As directed by the Mississippi PSC, Mississippi Power will amortize
the regulatory liability established pursuant to the Mississippi PSC&#146;s interim
order in December&nbsp;2003 as an increase to earnings as follows: $16.5&nbsp;million in
2004, $25.1&nbsp;million in 2005, $13.0&nbsp;million in 2006 and
$5.7&nbsp;million in 2007. This amortization increased after tax
earnings for the third quarter and year-to-date 2004 by $2.5 million
and $7.7 million, respectively.

<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
addition, the Mississippi PSC also approved Mississippi Power&#146;s
requested changes to its PEP rate schedule including the use of a
forward-looking test year, with appropriate oversight; annual, rather than
semi-
annual, filings; and certain changes to the performance indicator mechanisms.
Rate changes will be limited to 4% of retail revenues annually under the
revised PEP. The Mississippi PSC will review all aspects of PEP in 2007. See
Note 3 to the financial statements of Mississippi Power under &#147;Retail
Regulatory Filing&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K and Note (K)&nbsp;to the Condensed
Financial Statements herein.


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">83
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>MISSISSIPPI POWER COMPANY</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
RESULTS OF OPERATIONS AND FINANCIAL CONDITION



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><U>Storm Damage Cost
Recovery</U>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">During the month of September&nbsp;2004, Mississippi Power&#146;s service territory was
impacted by Hurricane Ivan. As mandated by the Mississippi PSC, Mississippi
Power maintains an accumulated provision for property damage to cover the cost
of damages from major storms to its transmission and distribution lines and the
cost of uninsured damages to it generation facilities and other property. The
total amount of damage related to this hurricane was estimated to be $7.6
million and was charged to the storm damage reserve in September&nbsp;2004, leaving
a balance in the reserve of $0.3&nbsp;million. See Note 1 to the financial
statements of Mississippi Power under &#147;Provision for Property Damage&#148; in Item&nbsp;8
of the Form 10-K and Note (K)&nbsp;to the Condensed Financial Statements herein for
more information.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><I>Other Matters</I>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">On October&nbsp;22, 2004, President Bush signed the American Jobs Creation Act of
2004 (the Jobs Act) into law. The Jobs Act represents the most significant
revision to the Internal Revenue Code since 1986. Congress must still develop
the regulations that will implement the requirements of the Jobs Act.
Mississippi Power is currently assessing the impact of the Jobs Act on its
taxable income. However, Mississippi Power currently does not expect the Jobs
Act to have a material impact on its financial statements.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Mississippi Power is subject to certain claims and legal actions arising
in the ordinary course of business. In addition, Mississippi Power&#146;s business
activities are subject to extensive governmental regulation related to public
health and the environment. Litigation over environmental issues and claims of
various types, including property damage, personal injury and citizen
enforcement of environmental requirements, has increased generally throughout
the United States. In particular, personal injury claims for damages caused by
alleged exposure to hazardous materials have become more frequent. The
ultimate outcome of such litigation against Mississippi Power cannot be
predicted at this time; however, management does not anticipate that the
liabilities, if any, arising from such current proceedings would have a
material adverse effect on Mississippi Power&#146;s financial statements.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;See the Notes to the Condensed Financial Statements herein for discussion
of various contingencies and other matters which may affect future earnings
potential.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>ACCOUNTING POLICIES</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Application of Critical Accounting Policies and Estimates</B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Mississippi Power prepares its financial statements in accordance with
accounting principles generally accepted in the United States. Significant
accounting policies are described in Note 1 to the financial statements of
Mississippi Power in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K. In the application of these
policies, certain estimates are made
that may have a material impact on Mississippi Power&#146;s results of operations
and related disclosures. Different
assumptions and measurements could produce estimates that are significantly
different from those recorded in the financial statements. See MANAGEMENT&#146;S
DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#151; ACCOUNTING POLICIES &#151; &#147;Application of Critical
Accounting Policies and Estimates&#148; of Mississippi Power in Item&nbsp;7 of the
Form 10-K for a complete discussion of Mississippi Power&#146;s critical accounting
policies and estimates related to Electric Utility Regulation, Contingent
Obligations, Plant Daniel Capacity and Plant Daniel Operating Lease. Also see
Note (K)&nbsp;to the Condensed Financial Statements herein for additional
information related to Plant Daniel capacity.



<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">84
</DIV>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">



<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>MISSISSIPPI POWER COMPANY</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
RESULTS OF OPERATIONS AND FINANCIAL CONDITION



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>New Accounting Standards</B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">On March&nbsp;31, 2004, Mississippi Power prospectively adopted FASB Interpretation
No.&nbsp;46R, &#147;Consolidation of Variable Interest Entities,&#148; which requires the
primary beneficiary of a variable interest entity to consolidate the related
assets and liabilities. The adoption of FASB Interpretation No.&nbsp;46R had no
impact on Mississippi Power&#146;s net income. However, as a result of the
adoption, Mississippi Power deconsolidated certain wholly-owned trusts
established to issue preferred securities, since Mississippi Power does not
meet the definition of
primary beneficiary established by FASB Interpretation No.&nbsp;46R. See Note (D)
to the Condensed Financial Statements herein for additional information related
to the adoption of FASB Interpretation No.&nbsp;46R.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In the third quarter 2004, Mississippi Power prospectively adopted FASB
Staff Position (FSP)&nbsp;106-2, Accounting and Disclosure Requirements related to
the Medicare Prescription Drug, Improvement, and Modernization Act of 2003 (the
Medicare Act). The Medicare Act provides a 28% prescription drug subsidy for
Medicare eligible retirees. FSP 106-2 requires recognition of the impacts of
the Medicare Act in the accumulated post-retirement benefit obligation (APBO)
and future cost of service for post-retirement medical plans and may be applied
retroactively to the enactment of the Medicare Act in December&nbsp;2003 or
prospectively effective for the third quarter 2004. Mississippi Power elected
to apply this treatment prospectively. The effect of the subsidy reduced
Mississippi Power&#146;s expenses for the three months ended September&nbsp;30, 2004 by
approximately $0.2&nbsp;million and is expected to have a similar impact on future
expenses. The subsidy&#146;s impact on the post-retirement medical plan APBO was a
reduction of approximately $8&nbsp;million. However, the ultimate impact on future
periods is subject to federal regulations governing the subsidy created in the
Medicare Act which are being finalized. See Note (G)&nbsp;to the Condensed Financial
Statements herein for additional information.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>FINANCIAL CONDITION AND LIQUIDITY</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Overview</B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Major changes in Mississippi Power&#146;s financial condition during the first nine
months of 2004 included the addition of approximately $45&nbsp;million to utility
plant, a reduction in current liabilities of $95&nbsp;million, an increase of $40
million in long-term debt, a decrease of $46&nbsp;million in cash and an increase in
accounts receivable of $24.2&nbsp;million. See Mississippi Power&#146;s Condensed
Statements of Cash Flows and &#147;Financing Activities&#148; herein for further details.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Capital Requirements and Contractual Obligations</B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#151; FINANCIAL CONDITION AND LIQUIDITY &#151;
&#147;Capital Requirements and Contractual Obligations&#148; of Mississippi Power in Item
7 of the Form 10-K for a description of Mississippi Power&#146;s capital
requirements for its construction program, lease obligations, purchase
commitments and trust funding requirements.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Sources of Capital</B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">In addition to the financing activities described herein, Mississippi Power
plans to obtain the funds required for
construction and other purposes from sources similar to those used in the past.
These sources include cash flows from operating activities and issuances of
unsecured debt, trust preferred securities, preferred stock and pollution
control bonds issued for Mississippi Power&#146;s benefit by public authorities. The
amount, type and timing of any financings, if needed, will depend upon
maintenance of adequate earnings, regulatory approval,



<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">85
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>
