<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>MISSISSIPPI POWER COMPANY</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
RESULTS OF OPERATIONS AND FINANCIAL CONDITION


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">prevailing market conditions and other factors. See BUSINESS &#151; &#147;Financing
Programs&#148; in Item&nbsp;1 of the Form 10-K for additional information.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;To meet short-term cash needs and contingencies, Mississippi Power had at
September&nbsp;30, 2004, approximately $23&nbsp;million of cash and cash equivalents and
$100&nbsp;million of unused committed credit arrangements with banks. Of these
facilities, $13&nbsp;million expire in 2004 and the remaining $87&nbsp;million expire in
2005. Approximately $37.5&nbsp;million of these credit arrangements contain
provisions allowing two-year term loans executable at the expiration date.
Mississippi Power expects to renew its credit facilities, as needed, prior to
expiration. The credit arrangements provide liquidity support to Mississippi
Power&#146;s obligations with respect to variable rate pollution control bonds and
commercial paper. Mississippi Power may also meet short-term cash needs
through a Southern Company subsidiary organized to issue and sell commercial
paper and extendible commercial notes at the request and for the benefit of
Mississippi Power and other Southern Company subsidiaries. At September&nbsp;30,
2004, Mississippi Power had $15&nbsp;million in commercial paper outstanding.
Management believes that the need for working capital can be adequately met by
utilizing lines of credit without maintaining large cash balances.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Off-Balance Sheet Financing Arrangements</B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">See MANAGEMENT&#146;S
DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#151; FINANCIAL CONDITION AND LIQUIDITY &#151;
&#147;Off-Balance Sheet Financing Arrangements&#148; in Item&nbsp;7 and Note 7 to the
financial statements of Mississippi Power under &#147;Operating Leases&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of
the Form 10-K for information related to Mississippi Power&#146;s lease of a
combined cycle generating facility at Plant Daniel.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Credit Rating Risk</B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Mississippi Power does not have any credit arrangements that would require
material changes in payment schedules or terminations as a result of a credit
rating downgrade. Mississippi Power is party to certain derivative agreements
that could require collateral and/or accelerated payment in the event of a
credit rating change to below investment grade. These agreements are primarily
for natural gas price risk management activities. At September&nbsp;30, 2004,
Mississippi Power had no material exposure related to these agreements.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Market Price Risk</B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Mississippi Power&#146;s market risk exposures relative to interest rate changes
have not changed materially compared with the December&nbsp;31, 2003 reporting
period. In addition, Mississippi Power is not aware of any facts or
circumstances that would significantly affect such exposures in the near term.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Due to cost-based rate regulation, Mississippi Power has limited exposure
to market volatility in interest rates, commodity fuel prices and prices of
electricity. To mitigate residual risks relative to movements in electricity
prices, Mississippi Power enters into fixed price contracts for the purchase
and sale of electricity through the wholesale electricity market. Mississippi
Power has also implemented retail fuel hedging programs at the instruction of
the Mississippi PSC and wholesale fuel hedging programs under agreements with
wholesale customers.

    <TD><DIV style="margin-left:10px; text-indent:-10px">Contracts at September

</DIV>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;For
additional information, see MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS
&#151;
FINANCIAL CONDITION AND LIQUIDITY &#151; &#147;Market Price Risk&#148; of Mississippi Power in
Item&nbsp;7 and Notes 1 and 6 to the financial statements of Mississippi Power under
&#147;Financial Instruments&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K and Note (F)&nbsp;to the
Condensed Financial Statements herein.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Financing Activities</B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">In March&nbsp;2004, Mississippi Power issued $40&nbsp;million of Series&nbsp;F Floating Rate
Senior Notes due March&nbsp;9, 2009. The proceeds from this sale, along with other
monies of Mississippi Power, were used to repay at maturity $80&nbsp;million
aggregate principal amount of Mississippi Power&#146;s Series&nbsp;D Floating Rate Senior
Notes due March&nbsp;12, 2004.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In April&nbsp;2004, Mississippi Power issued 1,200,000 Depositary Shares ($30
million aggregate stated capital), each representing one-fourth of a share of
5.25% Series&nbsp;Preferred Stock, cumulative, par value $100 per share. The
proceeds from this sale were primarily used to redeem other issues of higher
cost preferred stock and the remainder was used for general corporate purposes.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In addition to any financings that may be necessary to meet Mississippi
Power&#146;s capital requirements and contractual obligations, Mississippi Power
plans to continue, when economically feasible, a program to retire higher-cost
debt and replace these obligations with lower-cost capital if market conditions
permit.



<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">87
</DIV>

<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>SAVANNAH ELECTRIC AND POWER COMPANY</B><BR>
<DIV align="left">
<A name="140"></A>
</DIV>
<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
RESULTS OF OPERATIONS AND FINANCIAL CONDITION
</DIV>


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">THIRD QUARTER 2004 vs. THIRD QUARTER 2003<BR>
AND<BR>
YEAR-TO-DATE 2004 vs. YEAR-TO-DATE 2003



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>RESULTS OF OPERATIONS</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Earnings</B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Savannah Electric&#146;s net income after dividends on preferred stock for the third
quarter and year-to-date 2004 was $11.9&nbsp;million and $22.4&nbsp;million,
respectively, compared to $14.4&nbsp;million and $24.2&nbsp;million, respectively, for
the corresponding periods of 2003. Earnings decreased by $2.5&nbsp;million, or
17.4%, in the third quarter 2004 primarily due to higher operating expenses.
Year-to-date 2004 earnings were down by $1.8&nbsp;million, or 7.5%, as a result of
higher operating expenses, partially offset by higher operating revenues.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Significant income statement items appropriate for discussion include the
following:

<P>
<HR size="1" width="18%" align="left" noshade>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt">

<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" nowrap align="right">N/M</TD>
    <TD width="3%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="96%">Not meaningful</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Retail sales</I>. Excluding fuel revenues, which do not affect net income,
retail sales revenue remained stable in the third quarter 2004 and increased by
$6.5&nbsp;million, or 4.7%, year-to-date 2004 when compared to the corresponding
periods in 2003. The year-to-date 2004 increase in retail revenues is
primarily a result of favorable weather conditions in the first two quarters of
2004 and a 2.2% increase in the number of customers. Year-to-date 2004 energy
sales to residential and commercial customers were higher by 8.7% and 6.2%,
respectively. Industrial sales revenues, excluding fuel revenues, for
year-to-date 2004 remained essentially constant as compared to the same period
in 2003.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Fuel expense. </I>Fuel expense decreased in the third quarter and
year-to-date 2004 primarily as a result of a decrease in generation, partially
offset by higher cost of fuel. Generation decreased 14.3% for third quarter
and 4.0% for year-to-date 2004 when compared to the prior year because Savannah
Electric had opportunities to purchase power at prices less than its cost to
generate. Since fuel expenses are generally offset by fuel revenues through
Savannah Electric&#146;s fuel cost recovery clause, these expenses do not have a
significant impact on net income. See &#147;Future Earnings Potential &#151; FERC and
Georgia PSC Matters &#151; Fuel Cost Recovery Rate Filings&#148; and Note (L)&nbsp;to the
Condensed Financial Statements herein for additional information.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Purchased power &#151; non-affiliates. </I>In the third quarter and year-to-date
2004, the increases in purchased power from non-affiliates are primarily due to
higher demand and the opportunity to purchase this energy at a cost
lower than self-generation or than available from affiliates. These
transactions do not have a significant impact on earnings, as energy costs are
generally recovered through the fuel cost recovery clause.


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">93
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>SAVANNAH ELECTRIC AND POWER COMPANY</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
RESULTS OF OPERATIONS AND FINANCIAL CONDITION



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Purchased
power &#151; affiliates</I>. Purchased power from affiliates increased
in the third quarter and year-to-date 2004 as compared to the same periods in
the prior year primarily due to the availability of Southern Company system
generation at prices below self-generation to meet increased sales demand. The
capacity component of purchased power expense from affiliates is higher in
year-to-date 2004 reflecting a greater write-down of deferred Wansley PPA
costs, consistent with the accounting order approved by the Georgia PSC in
December&nbsp;2002, and higher capacity costs from affiliates.
See Note 3 to the financial statements of Savannah Electric
under &#147;Retail Regulatory Matters&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K for additional
information. The net impact of these transactions compared to the prior year
was a $0.4&nbsp;million decrease to expense for the third quarter and a $0.5&nbsp;million
increase year-to-date. Purchased power from affiliates also includes energy
purchases which will vary depending on demand and cost of generation resources
at each company. These energy costs are recovered through the fuel cost
recovery clause and have no significant impact on earnings.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Other
operations expense</I>. The increases for the third quarter and
year-to-date 2004 as compared to the same periods in the prior year in other
operations expense are attributed to increases in distribution expenses and
administrative and general expenses. Distribution expenses increased $0.4
million, or 19.5%, and $0.6&nbsp;million, or 10.7%, for the third quarter and
year-to-date 2004, respectively, primarily as a result of storm-related
expenses. Administrative and general expenses increased $0.5&nbsp;million, or 7.6%,
and $2.6&nbsp;million, or 14.4%, for the third quarter and year-to-date 2004,
respectively, primarily relating to accounting and auditing services, legal
expenses, workers&#146; compensation claims and employee benefit expenses.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Interest expense, net of amounts capitalized. </I>The third quarter and
year-to-date 2004 increases in this expense as compared to the same periods in
the prior year are mainly due to an increase in long-term debt outstanding of
$65&nbsp;million. These increases were more than offset by decreases in
distributions on mandatorily redeemable preferred securities. These preferred
securities were redeemed in January&nbsp;2004 with proceeds from senior notes issued
in late 2003.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Dividends on preferred stock. </I>Dividends on preferred stock increased for
the third quarter and year-to-date 2004 due to the issuance of 1,800,000 shares
($45&nbsp;million aggregate par value) of 6.00% Series&nbsp;Preferred Stock,
Non-Cumulative, Par Value $25 Per Share in June&nbsp;2004. See FINANCIAL CONDITION
AND LIQUIDITY &#151; &#147;Financing Activities&#148; herein for additional information.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Future Earnings Potential</B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">The results of operations discussed above are not necessarily indicative of
future earnings potential. The level of future earnings depends on numerous
factors including Savannah Electric&#146;s ability to maintain a stable regulatory
environment, to achieve energy sales growth while containing costs and to
recover costs related to growing demand and increasingly stricter environmental
standards. Growth in energy sales is subject to a number of factors, which
include weather, competition, new energy contracts with neighboring utilities,
energy conservation practiced by customers, the price of electricity, the price
elasticity of demand and the rate of economic growth in Savannah Electric&#146;s
service area. For additional information relating to these issues, see BUSINESS
&#150; The SOUTHERN System &#151; &#147;Risk Factors&#148; in Item&nbsp;1 and MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION
AND ANALYSIS &#151; RESULTS OF OPERATIONS &#151; &#147;Future Earnings Potential&#148; of Savannah
Electric in Item&nbsp;7 of the Form 10-K.

Actions</U>

to the Clean Air Act and other environmental
regulations could affect earnings if such costs cannot be recovered.
See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#151; RESULTS OF
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#151; RESULTS

<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>SAVANNAH ELECTRIC AND POWER COMPANY</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
RESULTS OF OPERATIONS AND FINANCIAL CONDITION


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">OF OPERATIONS &#151; &#147;Future Earnings Potential &#151; Environmental Matters&#148; of Savannah
Electric in Item&nbsp;7 and Note 3 to the financial statements of Savannah Electric
under &#147;New Source Review Actions&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K. As of March&nbsp;15,
2004, civil penalties under the Clean Air Act were increased prospectively to a
maximum of $32,500 per day, per violation. To the extent alleged violations
under the New Source Review litigation are deemed to be continuing, this
increased civil penalty amount could apply to such violations found to continue
after that date.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On May&nbsp;3, 2004, the U.S. Supreme Court denied the EPA&#146;s petition to review
the Eleventh Circuit Court of Appeals&#146; decision in the EPA&#146;s similar New Source
Review enforcement action against the TVA. The case against Savannah Electric
had been effectively stayed pending this final resolution of the TVA case. At
this time, no party to the case against Savannah Electric has sought to reopen
that case, which remains administratively closed in the District Court for the
Northern District of Georgia. An adverse outcome in this case could require
substantial capital expenditures and could possibly require payment of
substantial penalties that cannot be determined at this time. This could affect
future results of operations, cash flows and possibly financial condition if
such costs are not recovered through regulated rates.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><U>Global Warming Litigation</u>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">On July&nbsp;21, 2004, attorneys general from eight states, each outside of Southern
Company&#146;s service territory, and the corporation counsel for New York City
filed a complaint in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New
York against Southern Company and four other electric power companies. A
nearly identical complaint was filed by three environmental groups in the same
court. The complaints allege that the companies&#146; emissions of carbon dioxide, a
greenhouse gas, contribute to global warming, which the plaintiffs assert is a
public nuisance. Plaintiffs seek relief under the federal common law or, in the
alternative, under state law, of public nuisance. The environmental groups
also seek relief under common law private nuisance theories. The plaintiffs
seek a judicial order (1)&nbsp;holding each defendant jointly and severally liable
for creating, contributing to, and/or maintaining an ongoing public nuisance,
global warming and (2)&nbsp;permanently enjoining each of the defendants to abate
its contribution to the nuisance by capping its emissions of carbon dioxide and
then reducing those emissions by a specified percentage each year for at least
a decade. Plaintiffs have not, however, requested that damages be awarded in
connection with their claims. Southern Company believes these claims are
without merit and notes that the complaint cites no statutory or regulatory
basis for the claims. Southern Company and the other defendants have filed
motions to dismiss both lawsuits. Southern Company intends to vigorously defend
against these claims. While the outcome of this matter cannot be determined at
this time, an adverse judgment could result in substantial capital
expenditures.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><u>Other Environmental Matters</u>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">On April&nbsp;21, 2004, the EPA published
the final regional nitrogen oxide
reduction rules applicable to the State of Georgia. These rules specified that
the State of Georgia must submit a revised state implementation plan by April
2005, and affected sources must comply with the reduction requirements by May
1, 2007. However, on October&nbsp;22, 2004, the EPA announced it was granting a
petition for reconsideration filed with the EPA by a coalition of Georgia
industries. The EPA will stay implementation of the rule, as it relates to
the State of Georgia, while it initiates rulemakings to address the petition. The impact of
the nitrogen oxide reduction rules will depend on the outcome of the petition
for reconsideration and/or any subsequent development and approval of the State
of Georgia&#146;s state implementation plan and cannot be determined at this time.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On May&nbsp;5, 2004, the EPA published proposed amendments to its Regional Haze
rules with respect to Best Available Retrofit Technology guidelines and
requirements. The impact of these regulations will depend on the development
and implementation of the final rules and implementation by the state and
therefore cannot be determined at this time.

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">95
</DIV>

<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><I>FERC and Georgia PSC Matters</I>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><U>Market-Based Rate
Authority</U>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">See MANAGEMENT&#146;S
DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#151; RESULTS OF OPERATIONS &#151; &#147;Future
Earnings Potential &#151; FERC Matters &#151; Market-Based Rate Authority&#148; of Savannah
Electric in Item&nbsp;7 and Note 3 to the financial statements of Savannah Electric
under &#147;FERC Matters&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K. On April&nbsp;14, 2004, the FERC
issued an order that abandoned the SMA test and adopted a new interim analysis
for measuring generation market power. This new interim approach requires
utilities to submit a pivotal supplier analysis and a wholesale market share
analysis, the results of which provide a rebuttable presumption regarding
generation market power. The FERC&#146;s order also sets forth procedures for
rebutting these presumptions and addresses mitigation measures for those
entities that are found to have market power. In the absence of specific
mitigation measures, the order includes several cost-based mitigation measures
that would apply by default. The FERC also initiated a new rulemaking
proceeding that, among other things, will adopt a final methodology for
assessing generation market power.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On July&nbsp;8, 2004, the FERC denied Southern Company&#146;s request for rehearing,
along with a number of others, and reaffirmed the interim tests that it adopted
in April. Southern Company submitted the required analyses on August&nbsp;9, 2004.
In that filing, Southern Company passed the pivotal supplier analysis for all
markets and the wholesale market share analysis for all markets except the
Southern Company control area. Southern Company also submitted other analyses
to demonstrate that it lacks generation market power. This filing remains
pending at the FERC. Southern Company, along with other utilities, has also
filed an appeal of the FERC&#146;s April&nbsp;14, 2004 order with the Circuit Court of
Appeals in Washington, D.C. In the event that the FERC&#146;s default mitigation
measures are ultimately applied, Savannah Electric may be required to charge
cost-based rates for certain wholesale sales, which may be lower than
negotiated market-based rates. The final outcome of this matter will depend on
the form in which the final methodology for assessing generation market power
and mitigation rules may be ultimately adopted and cannot be determined at this
time.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><U>Transmission</U>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#150; RESULTS OF OPERATIONS &#151; &#147;Future
Earnings Potential &#151; FERC Matters &#151; Transmission&#148; of Savannah Electric in Item
7 of the Form 10-K for information on the FERC&#146;s order related to RTOs and the
FERC&#146;s notice of proposed rulemaking regarding open access transmission service
and standard electricity market design.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><U>Plant McIntosh
Construction Project</U>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#150; RESULTS OF OPERATIONS &#151; &#147;Future
Earnings Potential &#151; FERC Matters &#151; Southern Power PPAs&#148; of Savannah Electric
in Item&nbsp;7 and Note 3 to the financial statements of Savannah Electric under
&#147;FERC Matters&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K for information regarding PPAs
between Southern Power and Savannah Electric and Georgia Power for Plant
McIntosh capacity. In April&nbsp;2003, Southern Power applied for FERC approval of
these PPAs. In July&nbsp;2003, the FERC accepted the PPAs to become effective June
1, 2005, subject to refund, and ordered that hearings be held. To ensure the
timely completion of construction on McIntosh units 10 and 11 and their
availability in the summer of 2005 as supply side resources for the retail
customers in the State of Georgia, on May&nbsp;7, 2004, Savannah Electric and
Georgia
Power requested the Georgia PSC to direct them to acquire the McIntosh
construction project. Savannah Electric and Georgia Power proposed to place
the units in rate base at a cost approved by the Georgia PSC and to recover the
unit operation and maintenance costs as retail service expenses as may be
approved by the Georgia PSC. The Georgia PSC issued such an order on May&nbsp;18,
2004 and the transfer occurred on May&nbsp;24, 2004. On May&nbsp;20, 2004, Southern Power
filed a request to withdraw the PPAs and to terminate the ongoing



<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">96
</DIV>


<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">



<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>SAVANNAH ELECTRIC AND POWER COMPANY</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
RESULTS OF OPERATIONS AND FINANCIAL CONDITION


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">FERC proceedings. On August&nbsp;4, 2004, the FERC issued a notice that it allowed
the request to withdraw the PPAs to be accepted and to become effective by
operation of law on July&nbsp;20, 2004. However, the FERC made
no determination on what additional steps may need to be taken with respect to
testimony provided in the proceedings. The ultimate outcome of this matter
cannot now be determined.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The May&nbsp;18, 2004 Georgia PSC order also directed Georgia Power and
Savannah Electric to file an application within 10&nbsp;days of completing such
purchase to amend the resource certificate granted by the Georgia PSC in 2002
to describe the capacity resource as being the McIntosh units 10 and 11 (as
opposed to the McIntosh PPAs), the approximate construction schedule (which is
not expected to change) and the proposed rate base treatment. The application
was filed on June&nbsp;3, 2004 and the Georgia PSC will have 180&nbsp;days to respond.
The Georgia PSC is expected to review the application in accordance with its
affiliate transaction guidelines, which require a lower of cost or market
approach unless otherwise determined by the Georgia PSC. Georgia Power and
Savannah Electric have submitted information showing that the book cost of the
McIntosh construction project is lower than its market value. In direct
testimony filed on October&nbsp;14, 2004, the Georgia PSC staff proposed a different
valuation that shows the market value for the Plant McIntosh construction
project is less than book value. Georgia Power and Savannah Electric disagree
with the proposed valuation methodology. Georgia Power and Savannah Electric
plan to file rebuttal testimony in November with hearings being held in that
same month. The Georgia PSC is expected to issue a final order in this matter
in December&nbsp;2004. However, full recovery of the project costs depends on the
outcome of the Georgia PSC&#146;s review. In the event the Georgia PSC does not
allow full recovery of the project costs, then part of such costs may have to
be written off in accordance with FASB Statement No.&nbsp;90, &#147;Accounting for
Abandonments and Disallowed Plant Costs.&#148; At September&nbsp;30, 2004,
the investment in the McIntosh construction project totaled approximately $74.2
million for Savannah Electric. The ultimate outcome of the Georgia PSC&#146;s review
cannot now be determined. See Note (J)&nbsp;to the Condensed Financial Statements
herein for additional information.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><U>Fuel Cost Recovery Rate
Filings</U>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">On March&nbsp;23, 2004, Savannah Electric submitted a request to the Georgia PSC for
an accounting order which, if approved by the Georgia PSC, would have allowed
for the cost of a coal transloader then under construction to be amortized over
24&nbsp;months through fuel expense and recovered through Savannah Electric&#146;s fuel
cost recovery clause. The transloader allows foreign coal to be off-loaded
from ships at Savannah Electric&#146;s Plant Kraft dock and then transferred by rail
to Plant McIntosh. On June&nbsp;24, 2004, the Georgia PSC denied Savannah Electric&#146;s
request for this accounting order. Consequently, accumulated project costs were
recorded as construction work in progress in June&nbsp;2004 and were to be
depreciated over the project&#146;s estimated useful life of 35&nbsp;years once placed in
service.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On July&nbsp;30, 2004, Savannah Electric filed for a fuel cost recovery rate
increase with the Georgia PSC. The increase will allow for the recovery of fuel
costs based on an estimate of future costs, as well as the collection of the
existing under recovery of fuel expenses, over a two-year period. The amount
under recovered at September&nbsp;30, 2004 is approximately $14.5&nbsp;million and is
included in Savannah Electric&#146;s Condensed Balance Sheets herein. On October&nbsp;25,
2004, the Georgia PSC approved Savannah Electric&#146;s request, with no significant
modifications. The approved increase will allow for the recovery of
approximately $161&nbsp;million in fuel costs, which includes an estimate of future
fuel costs over the next twelve months and recovery of the existing under
recovered fuel balance, over the next 24&nbsp;months. The approved fuel rate
increase also includes the recovery of approximately $3.5&nbsp;million in costs
associated with the coal transloader to be amortized over a 21-month period,
which the Georgia PSC had denied in June&nbsp;2004. The new rates will become
effective in November&nbsp;2004. See Note (L)&nbsp;to the Condensed Financial Statements
herein for additional information.


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">97
</DIV>

<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><u>Retail Rate Case</u>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Savannah Electric is currently preparing testimony and exhibits for a base
retail rate case, which is expected to be filed with the Georgia PSC in late
November or early December&nbsp;2004. It is expected that an increase in retail
revenues will be requested to recover the investment in the McIntosh combined
cycle plant, continued investment in new transmission and distribution
facilities to support growth and improve reliability and increasing operating
expenses, in part, to meet new laws and regulations. A decision by the Georgia
PSC is expected in mid-year 2005.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><I>Other Matters</I>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">On October&nbsp;22, 2004, President Bush signed the American Jobs Creation Act of
2004 (the Jobs Act) into law. The Jobs Act represents the most significant
revision to the Internal Revenue Code since 1986. Congress must still develop
the regulations that will implement the requirements of the Jobs Act. Savannah
Electric is currently assessing the impact of the Jobs Act on its taxable
income. However, Savannah Electric currently does not expect the Jobs Act to
have a material impact on its financial statements.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;At the end of September, Kerr-McGee Corporation, one of Savannah
Electric&#146;s largest industrial customers, shut down one of its three production
lines at its Savannah, Georgia facility. The annual reduction in base revenues
is not expected to have a material impact on Savannah Electric&#146;s financial
statements.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Effective September&nbsp;30, 2004, Savannah Electric retired Units 4 and 5 at
Plant Riverside. The remaining units at the plant will be retired on May&nbsp;31,
2005. These retirements will have no material impact on Savannah Electric&#146;s
financial statements.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Savannah Electric is subject to certain claims and legal actions arising
in the ordinary course of business. In addition, Savannah Electric&#146;s business
activities are subject to extensive governmental regulation related to public
health and the environment. Litigation over environmental issues and claims of
various types, including
property damage, personal injury and citizen enforcement of environmental
requirements, has increased generally throughout the United States. In
particular, personal injury claims for damages caused by alleged
exposure to hazardous materials have become more frequent. The ultimate
outcome of such litigation against Savannah Electric cannot be predicted at
this time; however, management does not anticipate that the liabilities,
if any, arising from such current proceedings would have a material adverse
effect on Savannah Electric&#146;s financial statements.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;See the Notes to the Condensed Financial Statements herein for discussion
of various contingencies and other matters which may affect future earnings
potential.

Savannah Electric&#146;s results of operations and related disclosures. Different
assumptions and measurements could produce estimates that are significantly
different from those recorded in the financial statements. See MANAGEMENT&#146;S
DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#151; ACCOUNTING POLICIES &#151; &#147;Application of Critical
Accounting Policies and Estimates&#148; of Savannah Electric in Item&nbsp;7 of the

<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>New Accounting Standards</B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">On March&nbsp;31, 2004, Savannah Electric prospectively adopted FASB Interpretation
No.&nbsp;46R, &#147;Consolidation of Variable Interest Entities,&#148; which requires the
primary beneficiary of a variable interest entity to consolidate the related
assets and liabilities. See Note 6 to the financial statements of Savannah
Electric under &#147;Mandatorily Redeemable Preferred Securities&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the
Form 10-K regarding Savannah Electric&#146;s redemption of all
outstanding preferred securities in January&nbsp;2004 and the dissolution of the
issuing trust. Therefore, the adoption of Interpretation No.&nbsp;46R had no impact
on Savannah Electric&#146;s financial statements.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In the third quarter 2004, Savannah Electric prospectively adopted FASB
Staff Position (FSP)&nbsp;106-2, &#147;Accounting and Disclosure Requirements related to
the Medicare Prescription Drug, Improvement, and Modernization Act of 2003 (the
Medicare Act).&#148; The Medicare Act provides a 28% prescription drug subsidy for
Medicare eligible retirees. FSP 106-2 requires recognition of the impacts of
the Medicare Act in the accumulated post-retirement benefit obligation (APBO)
and future cost of service for post-retirement medical plans and may be applied
retroactively to the enactment of the Medicare Act in December&nbsp;2003 or
prospectively effective for the third quarter 2004. Savannah Electric elected
to apply this treatment prospectively. The effect of the subsidy reduced
Savannah Electric&#146;s expenses for the three months ended September&nbsp;30, 2004 by
approximately $0.1&nbsp;million and is expected to have a similar impact on future
expenses. The subsidy&#146;s impact on the post-retirement medical plan APBO was a
reduction of approximately $3.5&nbsp;million. However, the ultimate impact on future
periods is subject to federal regulations governing the subsidy created
in the Medicare Act being finalized. See Note (G)&nbsp;to the Condensed Financial
Statements herein for additional information.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>FINANCIAL CONDITION AND LIQUIDITY</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Overview</B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Major changes in Savannah Electric&#146;s financial condition during the first nine
months of 2004 included the addition of approximately $109.3&nbsp;million to utility
plant, which includes the Plant McIntosh combined cycle construction project.
See Note (J)&nbsp;to the Condensed Financial Statements herein for additional
information. The funds for these additions and other capital requirements were
derived primarily from operating activities, issuance of securities, capital
contributions from Southern Company and short-term debt. See Savannah
Electric&#146;s Condensed Statements of Cash Flows herein for further details.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Capital Requirements and Contractual Obligations</B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Reference is made to MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#150; FINANCIAL CONDITION
AND LIQUIDITY &#151; &#147;Capital Requirements and Contractual Obligations&#148; of Savannah
Electric in Item&nbsp;7 of the Form
10-K for a description of Savannah Electric&#146;s capital requirements for its
construction program, lease obligations, purchase commitments and trust funding
requirements. Approximately $31&nbsp;million will be required by September&nbsp;30, 2005
for maturities of long term debt. The projected construction program will
increase by $83.1&nbsp;million and $7.6&nbsp;million in 2004 and 2005, respectively, for
the Plant McIntosh combined cycle construction project and the
projected purchased power commitments will decrease by $25.3&nbsp;million in
2005-2006, $28.2&nbsp;million in 2007-2008 and $158.0&nbsp;million beyond 2008 as a
result of the purchase of the construction project.

</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">



<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>SAVANNAH ELECTRIC AND POWER COMPANY</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
RESULTS OF OPERATIONS AND FINANCIAL CONDITION



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Sources of Capital</B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Savannah Electric plans to obtain the funds required for construction and other
purposes from sources similar to those used in the past including both internal
and external funds. These sources include cash flows from operating activities
and issuances of unsecured debt, preferred stock and pollution control bonds
issued for Savannah Electric&#146;s benefit by public authorities and capital
contributions from Southern Company. The amount, type and timing of any future
financings, if needed, will depend upon market conditions and regulatory
approval. See BUSINESS &#151; &#147;Financing Programs&#148; in Item&nbsp;1 of the Form 10-K for
additional information.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Savannah Electric&#146;s current liabilities exceed current assets because of
the continued use of short-term debt as a funding source to meet cash needs,
which can fluctuate significantly due to the seasonality of the business. To
meet short-term cash needs and contingencies, Savannah Electric had at
September&nbsp;30, 2004 approximately $3.9&nbsp;million of cash and cash equivalents and
$50&nbsp;million of unused committed credit arrangements with banks, of which $10
million expires in 2004, $30&nbsp;million expires in 2005 and $10&nbsp;million expires in
2007. Of the unused credit arrangements expiring in 2004 and 2005, $40&nbsp;million
include two year term loan options executable at the expiration date. Savannah
Electric expects to renew its credit facilities, as needed, prior to
expiration. The credit arrangements provide liquidity support to some of
Savannah Electric&#146;s obligations with respect to its variable rate debt and its
commercial paper. Savannah Electric may also meet short-term cash needs through
a Southern Company subsidiary organized to issue and sell commercial paper and
extendible commercial notes at the request and for the benefit of Savannah
Electric and other Southern Company subsidiaries. At September&nbsp;30, 2004,
Savannah Electric had $12.8&nbsp;million of commercial paper and $8.0&nbsp;million of
extendible commercial notes outstanding. Management believes that the need for
working capital can be adequately met by utilizing lines of credit and access
to the financial markets.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Credit Rating Risk</B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Savannah Electric does not have any credit arrangements that would require
material changes in payment schedules or terminations as a result of a credit
rating downgrade. Savannah Electric is party to certain derivative agreements
that could require collateral and/or accelerated payment in the event of a
credit rating change to below investment grade. These agreements are primarily
for natural gas price risk management activities. At September&nbsp;30, 2004,
Savannah Electric had no material exposure related to these agreements.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Market Price Risk</B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Savannah Electric&#146;s market risk exposures relative to interest rate changes
have not changed materially compared with the December&nbsp;31, 2003 reporting
period. In addition, Savannah Electric is not aware of any facts or
circumstances that would significantly affect such exposures in the near term.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Due to cost-based rate regulations, Savannah Electric has limited exposure
to market volatility in interest rates, commodity fuel prices and prices of
electricity. To mitigate residual risks relative to movements in electricity
prices, Savannah Electric enters into fixed price contracts for the purchase
and sale of electricity through the wholesale electricity market and, to a
lesser extent, similar contracts for gas and oil purchases. Savannah Electric
has also implemented a retail fuel hedging program at the instruction of the
Georgia PSC.


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">100
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->

<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;For additional information, see MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS -
FINANCIAL CONDITION AND LIQUIDITY &#151; &#147;Market Price Risk&#148; of Savannah Electric in
Item&nbsp;7 and Notes 1 and 6 to the financial statements of Savannah Electric under
&#147;Financial Instruments&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K and Note (F)&nbsp;to the
Condensed Financial Statements herein.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Financing Activities</B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Savannah Electric received contributions to capital from Southern Company in
May&nbsp;2004 in the amount of $31&nbsp;million to help finance the purchase of the Plant
McIntosh construction project. See Note (J)&nbsp;to the Condensed Financial
Statements herein for additional information.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In June&nbsp;2004, Savannah Electric issued 1,800,000 shares ($45&nbsp;million
aggregate par value) of 6.00% Series&nbsp;Preferred Stock, Non-Cumulative, Par Value
$25 Per Share. The proceeds from this sale were used to repay a
portion of its outstanding short-term indebtedness that had been incurred
primarily to finance the purchase of the Plant McIntosh construction project.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Subsequent to September&nbsp;30, 2004, Savannah Electric has entered into
interest rate hedging transactions related to the anticipated issuance of
senior notes totaling approximately $30&nbsp;million. The notes are expected to be
issued in 2004. Further, Savannah Electric also entered into an interest rate
hedging transaction related to $13.9
million of its outstanding tax-exempt auction rate securities. The interest
rate swap will fix Savannah Electric&#146;s interest cost related to these
securities beginning in 2005 and continuing through 2007.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In addition to any financings that may be necessary to meet Savannah
Electric&#146;s capital requirements and contractual obligations, Savannah Electric
plans to continue, when economically feasible, a program to retire higher-cost
debt and replace these obligations with lower-cost capital if market conditions
permit.



<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">101
</DIV>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>SOUTHERN POWER COMPANY</B><BR>
CONDENSED BALANCE SHEETS (UNAUDITED)


<DIV align="center">
<TABLE style="font-size: 10pt" cellspacing="0" border="0" cellpadding="0" width="75%">
<!-- Begin Table Head -->
<TR valign="bottom">
    <TD width="62%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="10%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="7%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="10%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="7%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>
<TR style="font-size: 8pt" valign="bottom">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD nowrap align="center" colspan="3"><B>At September 30,</B></TD>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>SOUTHERN POWER COMPANY</B>


<DIV align="left">
<A name="146"></A>
</DIV>
<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<br>
RESULTS OF OPERATIONS AND FINANCIAL CONDITION</DIV>



<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">THIRD QUARTER 2004 vs. THIRD QUARTER 2003<BR>
AND<BR>
YEAR-TO-DATE 2004 vs. YEAR-TO-DATE 2003



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>RESULTS OF OPERATIONS</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Earnings</B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Southern Power&#146;s net income for the third quarter and year-to-date 2004 was
$37.3&nbsp;million and $86.9&nbsp;million, respectively, compared to $40.1&nbsp;million and
$142.5&nbsp;million for the corresponding periods of 2003. The decrease in third
quarter 2004 earnings of $2.8&nbsp;million, or 7.0%, is due to a reduction in the
earnings from sales of uncontracted capacity as new PPAs have become effective.
The decrease in year-to-date 2004 earnings of $55.6&nbsp;million, or 39.0%, is
primarily attributed to a one-time gain of $50&nbsp;million recognized in May&nbsp;2003
upon termination of PPAs with Dynegy, as well as the reduction in earnings from
sales of uncontracted capacity. PPAs with Alabama Power and Georgia Power for
Plants Harris Unit 1 and Franklin Unit 2 that began in June&nbsp;2003 and with the
Stanton joint owners for Stanton Unit A that began in October&nbsp;2003 increased
both affiliated and non-affiliated revenues, while significantly reducing
uncontracted capacity. A new PPA with Georgia Power for Plant Harris Unit 2
began in June&nbsp;2004 and further reduced uncontracted capacity. The previously
uncontracted capacity that was available to the market from June&nbsp;2003 through
May&nbsp;2004 consisted of approximately 800 MW: 600 MW from Plant Harris Unit 2 and
200 MW from Plant Franklin Unit 2.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Significant income statement items appropriate for discussion include the
following:

<DIV align="center">
<TABLE style="font-size: 10pt" cellspacing="0" border="0" cellpadding="0" width="75%">

<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Sales for resale &#151; non-affiliates</I>. The decrease in non-affiliate sales for
the third quarter 2004 relative to the same period in 2003 resulted from the
inception of Georgia Power&#146;s PPA for all the capacity of Plant Harris Unit 2 in
June&nbsp;2004; this capacity was therefore no longer available for non-affiliate
sales. Year-to-date 2004 revenues from sales for resale to non-affiliates were
higher when compared to the corresponding period in 2003. This increase was
primarily due to additional wholesale capacity and energy sales to
non-affiliates as a result of commercial operation of Plant Stanton A in
October&nbsp;2003.


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">107
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>SOUTHERN POWER COMPANY</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
RESULTS OF OPERATIONS AND FINANCIAL CONDITION



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Sales for resale &#151; affiliates. </I>During the third quarter 2004, sales for
resale to affiliates increased as compared to the same period in 2003 primarily
due to energy and capacity sales to Georgia Power that commenced in June&nbsp;2004
for Plant Harris Unit 2. For year-to-date 2004, revenues under this PPA, as
well as a full nine months of revenues in 2004 for PPAs at Plant Harris Unit 1
and Plant Franklin Units 1 and 2 that began in June&nbsp;2003 with both Alabama
Power and Georgia Power, contributed to the increase. Revenues from sales to
affiliated companies through the Southern Company system power pool and energy
sales under PPAs will vary depending on demand and the availability and cost of
generating resources accessible throughout the Southern Company system.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Fuel expense</I>. Fuel expense for the third quarter 2004 decreased when
compared to third quarter 2003 primarily as a result of the Plant Harris Unit 2
PPA with Georgia Power, under which Georgia Power assumes fuel responsibility.
Year-to-date 2004 fuel expense increased when compared to the same period in
2003 largely due to increased gas transportation expenses associated with Plant
Harris Unit 2 prior to its commitment under the Georgia Power PPA.
Significantly lower offsetting hedge gains in 2004 also contributed to the
year-to-date increase. Southern Power&#146;s existing PPAs generally provide that
the purchasers are responsible for substantially all of the cost of fuel
relating to the energy delivered under such PPAs; therefore, these cost
increases do not have a significant impact on net income.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Purchased power &#151; non-affiliates</I>. For third quarter 2004, the decrease
in purchased power &#151; non-affiliates when compared to the same period in 2003
is the result of lower demand due to milder weather and the availability of
lower priced energy from affiliates or self generation. The year-to-date 2004
increase over the same period in 2003 is attributable to the increase in lower
priced energy available from contracts with Georgia electric membership
corporations and North Carolina municipalities.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Purchased power &#151; affiliates</I>. The decrease in purchased power from
affiliates during the third quarter 2004 compared to the same period in the
prior year is the result of lower demand due to the milder weather and lower
relative cost of Southern Power&#146;s self generation. Expenses from purchased
power transactions will vary depending on demand, availability and the cost of
generating.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Other operations and maintenance expenses. </I>For the third quarter and
year-to-date 2004, other operations and maintenance expenses increased when
compared to the same periods in the prior year due mainly to expenses
associated with the commercial operation of Plant Franklin Unit 2 and Plant
Harris Units 1 and 2, which were all placed into commercial operation in June
2003, and Plant Stanton A, which was placed into commercial operation in
October&nbsp;2003.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Depreciation and amortization. </I>New generating units placed into service
in June and October&nbsp;2003 are the main reasons for the increases in depreciation
and amortization in the third quarter and year-to-date 2004 as compared to the
corresponding periods in the prior year.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Taxes other than income taxes. </I>During the third quarter 2004, taxes other
than income taxes decreased from the same period in 2003 due to lower property
tax rates resulting from a favorable settlement in the fourth quarter of 2003.
Year-to-date 2004 taxes other than income taxes increased over 2003 as a result
of the increased property tax base in October&nbsp;2003 when Plant Stanton A entered
service.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Interest expense, net of amounts capitalized. </I>In the third quarter and
year-to-date 2004, interest expense, net of amounts capitalized increased when
compared to the same periods in 2003 due to an increase in the amount of senior
notes outstanding and a lower percentage of interest costs being capitalized as
projects have reached completion. In addition, see Note (J)&nbsp;to the Condensed
Financial Statements herein for information


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">108
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>SOUTHERN POWER COMPANY</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
RESULTS OF OPERATIONS AND FINANCIAL CONDITION


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">regarding the transfer of the Plant McIntosh Units 10 and 11 construction
project to Georgia Power and Savannah Electric on May&nbsp;24, 2004. In August
2004, Southern Power completed limited construction activities at the Plant
Franklin Unit 3 to preserve the long-term viability of the project and
indefinitely suspended further construction. Capitalized interest was stopped
effective with the suspension date.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Other income (expense), net. </I>During the third quarter and year-to-date
2004, other income (expense), net increased due to gains on gas and electric
hedge positions, both realized and unrealized, and as a result of a state
taxable gain on the sale of Plant McIntosh Units 10 and 11 construction project
to Georgia Power and Savannah Electric.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Income taxes. </I>The increase in income taxes for the third quarter 2004 are
a direct result of the change in income items discussed above. The decrease in
income taxes year-to-date 2004 corresponds to the decrease in pre-tax earnings
due to the Dynegy settlement recorded in the second quarter of 2003.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Future Earnings Potential</B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">The results of operations are not necessarily indicative of future earnings.
The level of future earnings depends on numerous factors including completion
of construction on new generating facilities, regulatory matters including
those related to affiliate contracts, energy sales, creditworthiness of
customers, total generating capacity available in the Super Southeast and the
remarketing of capacity. Another major factor is federal regulatory policy,
which may impact Southern Power&#146;s level of participation in the wholesale
energy market. For additional information relating to these issues, see
Business &#151; The SOUTHERN System &#151; &#147;Risk Factors&#148;
in Item&nbsp;1 and MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#151; RESULTS OF OPERATIONS &#151;
&#147;Future Earnings Potential&#148; of Southern Power in Item&nbsp;7 of the Form 10-K.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><I>FERC Matters</I>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><u>Market-Based Rate
Authority</u>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#151; RESULTS OF OPERATIONS &#151; &#147;Future
Earnings Potential &#151; FERC Matters &#151; Market-Based Rate Authority&#148; of Southern
Power in Item&nbsp;7 and Note 3 to the financial statements of Southern Power under
&#147;FERC Matters&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K. On April&nbsp;14, 2004, the FERC issued
an order that abandoned the SMA test and adopted a new interim analysis for
measuring generation market power. This new interim approach requires
utilities to submit a pivotal supplier analysis and a wholesale market share
analysis, the results of which provide a rebuttable presumption regarding
generation market power. The FERC&#146;s order also sets forth procedures for
rebutting these presumptions and addresses mitigation measures for those
entities that are found to have market power. In the absence of specific
mitigation measures, the order includes several cost-based mitigation measures
that would apply by default. The FERC also initiated a new rulemaking
proceeding that, among other things, will adopt a final methodology for
assessing generation market power.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On July&nbsp;8, 2004, the FERC denied Southern Company&#146;s request for rehearing,
along with a number of others, and reaffirmed the interim tests that it adopted
in April. Southern Company submitted the required analyses on August&nbsp;9, 2004.
In that filing, Southern Company passed the pivotal supplier analysis for all
markets and the wholesale market share analysis for all markets except the
Southern Company control area. Southern Company also submitted other analyses
to demonstrate that it lacks generation market power. This filing remains
pending at the FERC. Southern Company, along with other utilities, has also
filed an appeal of the FERC&#146;s April&nbsp;14, 2004 order with the Circuit Court of
Appeals in Washington, D.C. In the event that the FERC&#146;s default mitigation measures are ultimately
applied, Southern Power may be required to charge cost-based rates
for certain wholesale sales,
which may be lower than negotiated market-based rates. The final


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">109
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>SOUTHERN POWER COMPANY</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
RESULTS OF OPERATIONS AND FINANCIAL CONDITION


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">outcome of this matter will depend on the form in which the final methodology
for assessing generation market power and mitigation rules may be ultimately
adopted and cannot be determined at this time.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><u>Plant McIntosh
Construction Project</u>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">See Note 3 to the financial statements of Southern Power under &#147;FERC Matters&#148;
in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K for information regarding PPAs between Southern
Power and Georgia Power and Savannah Electric for Plant McIntosh Units 10 and
11 capacity. In April&nbsp;2003, Southern Power applied for FERC approval of these
PPAs. In July&nbsp;2003, the FERC accepted the PPAs to become effective June&nbsp;1,
2005, subject to refund, and ordered that hearings be held. To ensure the
timely completion of construction on McIntosh Units 10 and 11 and their
availability in the summer of 2005 as supply side resources for the retail
customers in the State of Georgia, on May&nbsp;7, 2004, Savannah Electric and
Georgia Power requested the Georgia PSC to direct them to acquire the McIntosh
construction project. Savannah Electric and Georgia Power proposed to place
the units in rate base at a cost approved by the Georgia PSC and to recover the
unit operation and maintenance costs as retail service
expenses as may be approved by the Georgia PSC. The Georgia PSC issued such an
order on May&nbsp;18, 2004 and the transfer occurred on May&nbsp;24, 2004. On May&nbsp;20,
2004, Southern Power filed a request to withdraw the PPAs and to terminate the
ongoing FERC proceedings. On August&nbsp;4, 2004, the FERC issued a notice that it
allowed the request to withdraw the PPAs to be accepted and to become effective
by operation of law on July&nbsp;20, 2004. However, the FERC made no determination
on what additional steps may need to be taken with respect to testimony
provided in the proceedings. The ultimate outcome of this matter cannot now be
determined.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><u>Transmission</u>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#151; RESULTS OF OPERATIONS &#151; &#147;Future
Earnings Potential &#151; FERC Matters &#151; Transmission&#148; of
Southern Company in Item&nbsp;7
of the Form 10-K for information on the FERC&#146;s order related to RTOs and the
FERC&#146;s notice of proposed rulemaking regarding open access transmission service
and standard electricity market design.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><I>Power Sales Agreements</I>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">On August&nbsp;12, 2004, Southern Power entered into two PPAs with Florida Power &#038;
Light (FP&#038;L). Under the agreements, Southern Power will provide FP&#038;L with a
total of 790 megawatts of capacity annually from Plant Harris Unit 1 and Plant
Franklin Unit 1 for the period from June&nbsp;2010 through December&nbsp;2015. The PPAs
provide for fixed capacity payments and variable energy payments based on
actual energy delivered. Additionally, FP&#038;L will make payments for firm gas
transportation. These contracts are contingent upon certain events, including
approval of the Florida PSC. The final outcome of this matter cannot now be
determined.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Southern Power executed on August&nbsp;26, 2004 multiple agreements with a new
full-requirements customer. For the years 2005-2009, Southern Power will sell
approximately 130 megawatts of additional wholesale capacity from existing
resources to Flint Energies, a cooperative located in Reynolds, Georgia.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#151; RESULTS OF OPERATIONS &#151;
&#147;Future Earnings Potential &#151; General&#148; and &#147;- Power Sales Agreements&#148; of
Southern Power in Item&nbsp;7 of the Form 10-K
for additional information on long-term power sales agreements and PPAs.
Southern Power&#146;s PPAs with non-affiliated counterparties have provisions that
require the posting of collateral or an acceptable substitute
guarantee in the event that S&#038;P or Moody&#146;s downgrades the credit ratings of
such counterparty to below-investment grade, or, if the counterparty is not
rated, fails to maintain a minimum coverage ratio. The PPAs are expected to
provide Southern Power with a stable source of revenue during their respective
terms.


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">110
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>SOUTHERN POWER COMPANY</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
RESULTS OF OPERATIONS AND FINANCIAL CONDITION



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In June&nbsp;2003, Southern Power placed Plant Franklin Unit 2 and Plant Harris
Units 1 and 2 into commercial operation. In October&nbsp;2003, Southern Power placed
Plant Stanton A into commercial operation. In June&nbsp;2004, sales under PPAs with
Georgia Power for the remaining 200 MW of uncontracted capacity at Plant
Franklin Unit 2 and for Plant Harris Unit 2 began. Sales under PPAs for the
other units became effective upon commercial operation. The opportunity for
non-affiliate sales from uncontracted capacity has declined significantly since
these PPAs became effective.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><I>Other Construction Projects</I>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">In October&nbsp;2004, a partnership between Southern Company and the Orlando
Utilities Commission (OUC)&nbsp;was selected by the U.S. Department of Energy (DOE)
to build and operate a 285 MW coal-gasification facility. The facility will be
located at OUC&#146;s Stanton Energy Center near Orlando, Florida, site of the
existing gas-fired 630 MW Stanton A unit co-owned by Southern Power, OUC and
others. Southern Power will own and operate the Southern Company portion of the
project. The project will demonstrate a coal gasification technology that has
been under development, in partnership with the DOE, at Southern Company&#146;s
power systems development facility near Birmingham, Alabama. The project is
scheduled to begin commercial operation in early 2010, with a projected total
cost of $557&nbsp;million. The DOE will contribute approximately $235&nbsp;million of the
cost.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In August&nbsp;2004, Southern Power completed limited construction activities
on Plant Franklin Unit 3 to preserve the long-term viability of the project and
indefinitely suspended further construction. Final completion is not
anticipated until the 2008-2011 period. See Note 3 to the financial statements
of Southern Power under &#147;Uncontracted Generating Capacity&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the
Form 10-K for additional information. The final outcome of these matters
cannot now be determined.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><I>Other Matters</I>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">On October&nbsp;22, 2004, President Bush signed the American Jobs Creation Act of
2004 (Jobs Act) into law. The Jobs Act represents the most significant
revision to the Internal Revenue Code since 1986. Congress must still develop
the regulations that will implement the requirements of the Jobs Act. Southern
Power is currently assessing the impact of the Jobs Act on its taxable income.
However, Southern Power currently does not expect the Jobs Act to have a
material impact on its financial statements.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Southern Power is subject to certain claims and legal actions arising in
the ordinary course of business. In addition, Southern Power&#146;s business
activities are subject to extensive governmental regulation related to public
health and the environment. Litigation over environmental issues and claims of
various types, including property damage, personal injury and citizen
enforcement of environmental requirements, has increased generally throughout
the United States. In particular, personal injury claims for damages caused by
alleged exposure to hazardous materials have become more frequent. The ultimate
outcome of such litigation against Southern Power cannot be predicted at this
time; however, management does not anticipate that the liabilities, if any,
arising from such current proceedings would have a material adverse effect on
Southern Power&#146;s financial statements.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;See also the Notes to the Condensed Financial Statements herein for
discussion of various contingencies and other matters which may affect future
earnings potential.

Earnings Potential &#151; Environmental Matters&#148; of Southern Power in Item&nbsp;7 of the
Form 10-K for information on the

<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">development by federal and state environmental regulatory agencies of
additional control strategies for emission of air pollution from industrial
sources, including electric generating facilities. Compliance costs related to
current and future environmental laws and regulations could affect earnings if
such costs are not fully recovered.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>ACCOUNTING POLICIES</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Application of Critical Accounting Policies and Estimates</B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Southern Power prepares its financial statements in accordance with accounting
principles generally accepted in the United States. Significant accounting
policies are described in Note 1 to the financial statements of Southern Power
in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K. In the application of these policies, certain
estimates are made that may have a material impact on Southern Power&#146;s results
of operations and related disclosures. Different assumptions and measurements
could produce estimates that are significantly different from those recorded in
the financial statements. See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#151;
ACCOUNTING POLICIES &#151; &#147;Application of Critical Accounting Policies and
Estimates&#148; of Southern Power in Item&nbsp;7 of the
Form 10-K for a complete discussion of Southern Power&#146;s critical accounting
policies and estimates related to Revenue Recognition and Asset Impairments.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>FINANCIAL CONDITION AND LIQUIDITY</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Overview</B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">The major change in Southern Power&#146;s financial condition during the first nine
months of 2004 was the sale of the Plant McIntosh Units 10 and 11 combined
cycle construction project to Georgia Power and Savannah Electric at a final
book cost of $415&nbsp;million. See Note (J)&nbsp;to the Condensed Financial Statements
herein for additional information. As a result of the sale, Southern Power
repaid its note payable to Southern Company of $89&nbsp;million, returned $225
million to Southern Company ($113&nbsp;million from capital surplus and $112&nbsp;million
from retained earnings) and repaid $114&nbsp;million in commercial paper borrowings.
In September&nbsp;2003, the SEC had approved, under the PUHCA, Southern Power&#146;s
payment of dividends in an amount up to $190&nbsp;million to Southern Company from
capital surplus. In September&nbsp;2004, Southern Power declared and paid $75
million in additional dividends to Southern Company, bringing the
dividends paid out of retained earnings to $187&nbsp;million.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Capital Requirements and Contractual Obligations</B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Reference is made to MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#151; FINANCIAL CONDITION
AND LIQUIDITY &#151; &#147;Capital Requirements and Contractual Obligations&#148; of Southern
Power in Item&nbsp;7 of the Form 10-K for a description of Southern Power&#146;s capital
requirements for its construction program, maturing debt, purchase commitments
and long-term service agreements. The sale of the Plant McIntosh Units 10 and
11 construction project and the suspension of construction activities at Plant
Franklin Unit 3 have eliminated the current need for short-term borrowings
under the commercial paper program. The projected construction program will
decrease by $202&nbsp;million and $41&nbsp;million in 2004 and 2005, respectively, for
the Plant McIntosh combined cycle construction project as a result of the sale
of the project.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Sources of Capital</B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">In February&nbsp;2003, Southern Power initiated a commercial paper program to fund a
portion of the construction costs of new generating facilities. The amount of
commercial paper initially represented approximately 45% of
total debt, but proceeds from the sale of the Plant McIntosh Units 10 and 11
construction project were used to repay $24&nbsp;million of outstanding commercial
paper early in the third quarter of 2004. Southern Power&#146;s strategy



<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">112
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">



<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>SOUTHERN POWER COMPANY</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
RESULTS OF OPERATIONS AND FINANCIAL CONDITION


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">has been to refinance most of such short-term borrowings with long-term
securities following commercial operation of the generating facilities. At
September&nbsp;30, 2004, there was no commercial paper outstanding. See Note 6 to
the financial statements of Southern Power under &#147;Commercial Paper&#148; in Item&nbsp;8
of the Form 10-K for additional information.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;To meet liquidity and capital resource requirements, Southern Power had at
September&nbsp;30, 2004 $19.3&nbsp;million in cash and equivalents and $325&nbsp;million of an
unused committed credit arrangement with banks expiring in 2006. Reflecting the
change in Southern Power&#146;s future construction needs following the sale of the
McIntosh construction project, the committed credit arrangement was reduced
from $650&nbsp;million to $325&nbsp;million. This arrangement also provides liquidity
support for Southern Power&#146;s commercial paper program. Amounts drawn under the
arrangements may be used to finance acquisition and construction costs related
to gas-fired electric generating facilities and for general corporate purposes,
subject to borrowing limitations for each generating facility. The
arrangements permit Southern Power to fund construction of future generating
facilities upon meeting certain requirements. Southern Power expects to renew
its credit facility, as needed, prior to expiration.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Credit Rating Risk</B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Southern Power does not have any credit arrangements that would require
material changes in payment schedules or terminations as a result of a credit
rating downgrade. There are contracts that could require collateral &#151; but not
accelerated payment &#151; in the event of a credit rating change to below
investment grade. These contracts are primarily for physical electricity
purchases and sales, fixed-price physical gas purchases and agreements covering
interest rate swaps. Generally, collateral may be provided by a Southern
Company guaranty, letter of credit or cash. At September&nbsp;30, 2004, the maximum
potential collateral requirements were approximately $179&nbsp;million.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Southern Power is also party to certain derivative agreements that could
require collateral and/or accelerated payment in the event of a credit rating
change to below investment grade. These agreements are primarily for natural
gas price risk management activities. At September&nbsp;30, 2004, Southern Power
had no material exposure related to these agreements.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Market Price Risk</B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Southern Power&#146;s market risk exposures relative to interest rate changes have
not changed materially compared with the December&nbsp;31, 2003 reporting period.
In addition, Southern Power is not aware of any facts or circumstances that
would significantly affect such exposures in the near term.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Because energy from Southern Power&#146;s generating facilities is primarily
sold under long-term PPAs with tolling agreements and provisions shifting
substantially all of the responsibility for fuel cost to the purchasers,
Southern Power&#146;s exposure to market volatility in commodity fuel prices and
prices of electricity is limited. To mitigate residual risks in those areas,
Southern Power enters into fixed-price contracts for the sale of electricity.


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">113

ALABAMA POWER COMPANY<BR>
